Germans and Americans differ significantly in their perceptions of the leading economic power. Half of Americans believe the U.S. is the leading economic power, while a third (32%) name China [2]. In contrast, 53% of Germans identify China as the leading economic power, with only 24% naming the U.S. [2]. This is visually represented in a bar chart showing these differing opinions across age groups in Germany.![The older the age, the less likely people are to name the USA as the world’s leading economic power, but this trend does not exist for China.](image3)

Regarding international relationships, Germans generally view international nations and organizations more favorably than Americans do [8]. The European Union (EU) exemplifies this difference: about 70% of Germans favor the EU, compared to only about half of Americans [8]. The favorability difference is clearly visualized with a bar chart.![Germany is more favorable than USA on EU, Russia, China, UN, and NATO.](image5)

The views also diverge when it comes to China. Germans are more likely to view China positively (34%) compared to Americans (26%) [image5].

In conclusion, Americans and Germans differ significantly in their views of the leading economic power, with Americans naming the U.S. and Germans naming China, and they also hold differing views on international relationships, with Germans generally more favorable toward the EU and China.

Americans and Germans hold distinct views on international organizations and global economic powers, influenced by factors such as political ideology and geographical location within Germany.

Germans generally view international organizations more favorably than Americans [10]. This is particularly evident in the case of the European Union (EU), where approximately 70% of Germans have a positive view, compared to only about 50% of Americans [10]. A similar gap exists for perceptions of Russia, though favorability is lower in both countries [10].
![32-country median of favorability towards the EU, Russia, China, UN, and NATO](image1)
There is more consensus on the United Nations (UN) and NATO, but Germans still tend to view these organizations more positively [10].

Political ideology significantly impacts these views [3]. In both countries, conservatives and those on the right are more likely to view Russia favorably than liberals and those on the left [3]. Conversely, liberals and those on the left are more likely to favor the UN and EU [3]. This ideological divide is notably wider among Americans than among Germans [3].
![Ideological differences in views of the UN, EU and Russia](image4)
Geographical location within Germany also plays a role. Germans living in former East Germany tend to view Russia more favorably and the EU less favorably than those living in the former West [5].

When it comes to the world's leading economic power, Americans and Germans have starkly different opinions [7]. Half of Americans name the U.S., while roughly half of Germans name China [7].
![Leading economic power as percieved by Germans](image3)
Few in either country see Japan or the countries of the European Union as the leading economic power [7, 8].
![Leading economic power as percieved by Americans](image2)
In summary, Americans and Germans differ in their views of international organizations and economic powers, with Germans generally more favorable towards international organizations and more likely to see China as the leading economic power, influenced by factors like political ideology and, in Germany, geographical location.

Americans are much more inclined to believe in the necessity of military force to maintain global order, with approximately eight-in-ten Americans agreeing with this stance [4]. Americans and Germans hold significantly different views on military intervention and defense spending.

American and German opinions differ significantly on military intervention, with Americans more supportive, and on defense spending, with Americans mostly wanting European allies to maintain current spending levels while Germans are split on increasing or maintaining their defense budget.

American and German opinions on defense spending have shifted over the years, with evolving partisan differences within each country.

In the U.S., there's been a notable shift in opinion regarding European allies' defense spending. Half of Americans believe that spending levels should remain the same [5], which means that fewer American see the defense spending of European allies important. This contrasts with 2017, when 45% of Americans felt their European allies should dedicate more resources to national defense [5].

![Should our European allies __ spending on national defense? Should Germany __ spending on national defense?](image5)

In Germany, the public is divided on whether to increase or maintain current levels of spending on national defense, with about four-in-ten taking each view [7]. This also marks a change from 2017, when about half of Germans were content with their country's defense spending, while about a third felt it should be increased [7].

Partisan gaps are evident in both countries. In the U.S., Republicans and Republican-leaning independents are more likely than Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents to favor increased defense spending in Europe [8]. However, even among Republicans, the share favoring increased defense budgets for European allies has fallen by 14 percentage points between 2017 and 2019 [8].

![Republican/Lean Rep Democrat/Lean Dem](image2)

In Germany, supporters of the CDU/CSU are generally in favor of defense spending increases [1]. Supporters of the Greens are more skeptical, with only 28% wanting to raise defense spending [1]. Members of the SPD fall in the middle, with 41% saying Germany should increase defense spending [1].

In summary, American and German opinions on defense spending have changed over time, with Americans showing less insistence on European allies increasing their defense budgets, and Germans divided on the issue. Partisan differences are present in both countries, influencing views on defense spending.

American views on whether European allies should increase national defense spending have shifted since 2017. In 2017, 45% of Americans believed European allies should dedicate more resources to national defense [4]. However, by 2019, half of Americans believed that spending levels should remain the same [4].
![Should our European allies  spending on national defense? Should Germany  spending on national defense?](image1)

In the U.S., there's a partisan divide. Republicans and Republican-leaning independents are more likely than Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents to favor increased defense spending in Europe [3]. However, the percentage of Republicans who think European allies should increase their defense budgets has fallen by 14 percentage points between 2017 and 2019 [3].
![Republican/Lean Rep Democrat/Lean Dem](image3)

Germans are divided on whether to increase or maintain current levels of spending on national defense, with about four-in-ten taking each view [10]. This represents a change from 2017, when about half of Germans were content with their country's defense spending, while about a third felt it should be increased [10]. In Germany, partisan gaps also emerge, with supporters of the CDU/CSU favoring defense spending increases, Greens expressing skepticism, and SPD members falling in the middle [9].

In Summary: American views have shifted towards maintaining current defense spending levels in Europe, while Germans are divided between increasing or maintaining their defense budget. Both countries exhibit partisan differences in opinions on defense spending.

In the U.S., there's a noticeable partisan divide regarding defense spending in Europe. Republicans and Republican-leaning independents are more inclined to support increased defense spending by European allies compared to Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents [3]. However, this support among Republicans has decreased by 14 percentage points between 2017 and 2019, with a smaller decline also observed among Democrats [3].
![Should our European allies __ spending on national defense? Should Germany __ spending on national defense?](image1)
In Germany, partisan gaps also exist [5]. Supporters of the CDU/CSU generally favor increasing defense spending [5].
![Republican/Lean Rep Democrat/Lean Dem](image5)
Members of the SPD are more মাঝামা divided, while supporters of the Greens show more skepticism, with a smaller percentage wanting to raise defense spending [5].

Political affiliations influence opinions on defense spending, with conservatives generally more supportive and liberals less so, and these views have shown some decline over time, particularly among U.S. Republicans.

In Germany, there's a significant generational gap in how people view the importance of U.S. military bases. Younger Germans, aged 18-29, are largely skeptical, with about six-in-ten believing that these bases do *not* contribute to German national security [9]. ![Perceptions of importance by age group.](image5) This contrasts sharply with older Germans (65 and older), where a majority (61%) believe the bases *are* important to Germany's defense [9]. Overall, while about half of Germans see U.S. military bases as important, 45% disagree, indicating a notable level of dissent [8].

In the U.S., political affiliation influences views on foreign policy partners [4]. Both Republicans and Democrats consider the UK their most important partner [4].
![Top foreign policy partners by political affiliation.](image4)
However, Republicans show a stronger preference for Israel (26%) compared to Democrats (9%) [4]. Democrats, on the other hand, place more emphasis on Canada and Mexico [4]. Despite these differences, both parties rank Germany similarly, as the fifth most important foreign policy partner [4]. While there are partisan divides on military presence in germany, both parties express high support for the american military in germany. [10].

Age differences in Germany and political affiliations in the U.S. significantly impact perceptions: younger Germans doubt the importance of U.S. military bases, while older Germans mostly support them; in the U.S., Republicans and Democrats share some common ground on foreign policy partners like the UK and Germany but diverge on the importance of others like Israel, Canada, and Mexico.

Americans' views on global engagement and handling of international issues, particularly concerning the coronavirus outbreak, exhibit significant differences based on political affiliation and educational background.

Regarding global engagement, a majority of Republicans (75%) believe the U.S. should focus on its own problems and let other countries manage on their own [5]. Democrats, however, are more divided, with over half believing the U.S. should help other countries, and 46% prioritizing domestic issues [8]. This ideological divide is evident within the Democratic party, with 64% of liberal Democrats favoring international aid compared to 44% of conservative and moderate Democrats [8].
![Americans are divided on whether the U.S. should deal with its own problems or help other countries.](image3)

Educationally, a clear trend emerges: higher levels of education correlate with greater support for helping other nations [10]. Sixty percent of postgraduates advocate for the U.S. to assist other countries, while college graduates are evenly split, and majorities of those with some college or a high school diploma believe the U.S. should focus on its own problems [10].

When it comes to evaluating the U.S.'s handling of the coronavirus outbreak, partisan differences are stark. About three-quarters of Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents (73%) are critical of the U.S.'s response, while a similar share of Republicans and Republican-leaning independents (71%) praise the country's handling [9].
![Different groups have different opinions on the U.S. response to the coronavirus.](image4)
Furthermore, around two-thirds of those with a postgraduate degree say the U.S. has done a poor job, as do around six-in-ten college graduates, and 43% of high school degree or less say the same [3].

In conclusion, views on U.S. global engagement and its handling of international issues are significantly divided along political lines, with Republicans favoring a focus on domestic issues and Democrats more split, and higher education levels correlate with greater support for international cooperation.

Americans' views on the handling of the COVID-19 pandemic by both the U.S. and China are significantly shaped by their political affiliations and, to a lesser extent, their educational backgrounds.

A stark partisan divide exists in evaluating the U.S. response. A significant majority of Republicans and Republican-leaning independents (71%) believe the U.S. has handled the outbreak well [3, 10]. Conversely, a similarly large majority of Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents (73%) are critical of the U.S.'s response [3]. This partisan split is visually represented as well.
![Partisan divide in the evaluation of the U.S. handling of COVID-19, with Democrats being more critical.](image2)

Education level also plays a role in assessing the U.S. response, though the impact is secondary to political affiliation. More educated Americans tend to be more critical. Around two-thirds of those with a postgraduate degree express dissatisfaction with the U.S. response, a view shared by about six-in-ten college graduates. In contrast, only 43% of those with a high school diploma or less hold the same negative view [2].
![The good and poor rating of US handling the pandemic.](image5)

When it comes to China's handling of the pandemic, political affiliation is less of a factor [4]. A large majority of Americans (nearly two-thirds) believe China has not done a good job. While the split among Republicans and Democrats in rating China's response is much less, still 22% more of Democrats have a negative rating than the Republicans.
![A visual representation of the opinions of the U.S. citizens on how China is handling the pandemic.](image2)
There is also a slight correlation with age, with older Americans being more critical of China's performance [7]. Education, however, plays little role in shaping these opinions [4].

In conclusion, political affiliation is the primary driver of Americans' perceptions of the U.S. response to the COVID-19 pandemic, while education level plays a secondary, moderating role; however, both factors have lesser impact on views about China.

There's a stark partisan divide in how Americans perceive their country's response to the COVID-19 pandemic [2]. A significant majority of Republicans and Republican-leaning independents (71%) believe the U.S. has done a good or excellent job, while only 27% of Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents share this view [8]. This difference is visually represented in a chart, showing a 44-percentage-point gap between the two groups.
![Chart showing the partisan divide in the perception of the U.S.'s handling of the pandemic.](image2)

Conversely, perceptions of China's handling of the pandemic, while generally negative across the board, also show partisan differences [9]. Republicans are much more likely than Democrats to say China has not handled the crisis well [9].

![A chart representing different demographics' opinions on the U.S.'s handling of the pandemic.](image4)
In the context of China, most Americans, regardless of education level, believe that China has not handled the pandemic well [7].

Political affiliations clearly influence perceptions, with Republicans viewing the U.S. response more favorably and China's response more negatively than Democrats [8, 9].

Americans' views on whether the U.S. can learn from other countries in handling the coronavirus outbreak vary significantly across political lines. A majority of Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents (60%) believe the U.S. can learn "a great deal" from other countries, compared to only 28% of Republicans and Republican leaners [6]. This partisan divide is even more pronounced regarding trust in international organizations.

For instance, 86% of liberal Democrats say they trust information from the WHO at least a fair amount, while only 27% of conservative Republicans share this view [10]. This difference of 59 percentage points highlights the significant gap in trust between the two groups.
![WHO](image1)

Similarly, although somewhat smaller divisions also exist in trust in information from the EU [10].
![EU](image1)
Those who believe the U.S. can learn from other countries tend to rate the performance of those countries more positively [7]. This is evident across party lines, as Republicans who believe the U.S. can learn from others are more likely to view other countries' handling of the pandemic favorably, and the same pattern is observed among Democrats [8].
![Germany](image2)

Overall, majorities say they trust data from the European Union and WHO [4].
![WHO and EU](image3)

Perceptions of the U.S.'s ability to learn from other countries in handling the coronavirus differ significantly between political affiliations, with Democrats generally more open to learning from other countries and trusting international organizations like the WHO and EU compared to Republicans.

Americans' views on whether the U.S. should prioritize its own problems or assist other countries vary significantly based on political affiliation and educational attainment.

A majority of Americans (60%) believe the U.S. should deal with its own problems and let other countries manage on their own [2]. This sentiment is particularly strong among Republicans, with about three-quarters favoring this approach [6].
![Republicans largely believe the U.S. should focus on its own problems and let other countries deal with their own problems as best they can.](image5)
Conversely, Democrats are more divided, though a majority still lean towards the U.S. helping other countries [4]. There's a notable ideological split within the Democratic party: 64% of liberal Democrats advocate for helping other countries, compared to 44% of conservative and moderate Democrats [4].

Educational background also influences these views. Individuals with higher levels of education are more inclined to support the U.S. aiding other nations [9].
![Postgraduates are most likely to believe the US should deal with other countries' problems.](image5)
Six-in-ten postgraduates believe the U.S. should help other countries, while college graduates are evenly split. In contrast, clear majorities of those with some college or less education believe the U.S. should focus on its own problems [9].

In summary, Republicans and those with lower educational levels are more likely to believe the U.S. should focus on its own problems, while Democrats, especially liberal Democrats, and those with higher education levels are more likely to support the U.S. helping other countries.

There's a significant partisan divide in opinions regarding America's role in solving global issues, with Republicans and Democrats holding contrasting views that have diverged over time.

A majority of Republicans (62%) believe the U.S. does too much to help solve world problems [3]. This perspective is visually represented over time, showing a notable increase from 52% in 2018 to 62% in 2020.  ![A majority of republicans think US does too much to help solve world problems.](image3)

About three-quarters of Republicans prefer the U.S. to focus on its own problems and allow other countries to manage independently [8]. This is further supported by data showing a strong inclination among Republicans to prioritize domestic issues.  ![Republicans are much more likely than Democrats to say that the country should deal with its own problems.](image2)

Conversely, a plurality of Democrats (48%) think the U.S. does too little to help solve world problems [3]. The trend data indicates that this view has slightly increased since 2018. ![A plurality of democrats think US does too little to help solve world problems.](image5)

More than half of Democrats believe the U.S. should assist other countries in dealing with their problems [7]. However, there is an ideological divide within the Democratic Party, with 64% of liberal Democrats favoring international assistance compared to 44% of conservative and moderate Democrats [7]. The divide was far less pronounced in previous years [6].

In conclusion, Republicans predominantly believe the U.S. does too much in solving world problems and should focus domestically, while a significant portion of Democrats believe the U.S. should do more to help other countries.

Americans show varied levels of concern about specific issues in the U.S.-China relationship [10]. About three-quarters or more say that each issue is at least somewhat serious [10]. Four problems stand out as ones that half or more describe as *very* serious: cyberattacks from China, the loss of U.S. jobs to China, China’s growing military power, and China’s policies on human rights [10]. For example, 65% consider cyberattacks from China to be a "very serious" problem, and 26% find them "somewhat serious," totaling 91% [image4].

![Cyberattacks from China very serious problem](image4)

Around half of Americans (53%) have confidence that Biden will be able to deal effectively with China [2]. However, this is the lowest confidence level among six issues tested, including improving relationships with allies, dealing with terrorism and global climate change, and making good decisions about military force and international trade [2]. For example, 67% of the respondent have confidence to improve relationships with allies and only 53% of the respondents have confidence in dealing effectively with China.

![Improve relationships with our allies](image1)

Americans have less faith in Biden to deal with China than to handle other foreign policy issues [1, 7].

Americans have varying levels of confidence in Biden's ability to deal effectively with China, with noticeable differences across demographic groups [2, 10]. Women (59%) show more confidence in Biden's ability to deal with China than men (48%) [10]. Black (82%) and Hispanic adults (70%) express significantly more confidence than White adults (43%) [10]. Additionally, those with a college degree are more confident (60%) than those without (50%) [10].

Partisan differences are stark, with 83% of Democrats and Democratic-leaning individuals expressing confidence, compared to only 19% of Republicans and Republican-leaning individuals [3]. This confidence level further diverges within the Republican party, with only 10% of conservative Republicans having confidence, compared to 30% of moderate or liberal Republicans [3].
![Confidence in dealing with several countries](image4)
Americans express significant concerns over several aspects of the U.S.-China relationship [5]. The most pressing issues, identified as "very serious" by half or more of the respondents, include cyberattacks from China, the loss of U.S. jobs to China, China's growing military power, and China's human rights policies [5].
![Serious problems of China](image3)
Other concerns, though considered less critical, still garner substantial attention, such as China's growing technological power and the U.S. trade deficit with China [6, image3]. Protecting the jobs of American workers are at the top foreign policy goals.
![Foreign policy goals](image1)
In summary, confidence in Biden's ability to handle China varies significantly across demographic groups, particularly along racial, educational, and partisan lines, with primary concerns about China focusing on cyberattacks, job losses, military power, and human rights.

In conclusion, different political affiliations in the U.S. generally agree on prioritizing human rights over economic relations with China, but differ on trade issues, with Republicans favoring a tougher stance and Democrats preferring stronger economic ties.

Conservative Republicans are especially likely to hold this view, while moderate or liberal Republicans are more divided [2].

In contrast, about six-in-ten Democrats and Democrat-leaning independents favor building stronger ties with China [1]. Democrats mostly say that tariffs were bad for the U.S. [2].

However, personal experience with the tariffs does not differ much based on geography or income, that most feel that trade war didn't affect them personally[5].
![= Bad No real effect Good You](image4)

In summary, Republicans generally favor a tougher stance on China and are more likely to view tariffs positively, while Democrats prefer building a stronger relationship and are more likely to see tariffs as detrimental.

Americans' views on tariffs and international students vary significantly based on political affiliation.

Republicans are more likely to believe that tariffs on Chinese and other foreign goods have a positive effect on the U.S. [1]. About half of Republicans say increased tariffs on Chinese and other foreign products were good for the U.S., with conservative Republicans showing stronger support [10]. Democrats, in contrast, most often say the tariffs were bad for the U.S. [10].

In conclusion, Republicans generally view tariffs positively and are more likely to support limits on Chinese students, while Democrats generally view tariffs negatively and strongly support international students, including those from China.

Americans are divided on the issue of limiting Chinese students studying in the U.S., with a majority (55%) supporting such limitations [6, 7]. This sentiment varies significantly across age and political affiliation.

Older Americans are more likely to support limiting Chinese students [3]. Specifically, roughly seven-in-ten Americans aged 50 and older favor limitations [3]. Support decreases with age; those aged 30 to 49 are evenly split, and nearly two-thirds of Americans aged 18 to 29 oppose the idea.
![Support limiting Chinese students](image4)

Republicans are more likely than Democrats to favor restrictions on the number of Chinese students [3]. Republicans are also more inclined to have negative views of China. [1].

The inclination to get the U.S should be tougher on China, on economic issues [1]. A person stated, "We rely TOO MUCH on goods from China. China is trying to dominate the whole world and we are supporting that with the stuff we buy from them. Too bad their scientists seem to be smarter than ours. And they are welcomed here as students. We have to stop kissing up to China.” [2].

Confidence in Chinese President Xi Jinping also varies by age and political affiliation. Older Americans are more likely to have no confidence in Xi [10].
![No confidence at all in Xi](image1)

In summary, older Americans and Republicans are more likely to support limiting Chinese students in U.S. universities and express lower confidence in Chinese leadership, while younger Americans and Democrats show more opposition to these limitations and slightly more confidence in Xi.

American perceptions of China have become significantly more negative between 2018 and 2021, with a substantial increase in the share of Americans holding "cold" feelings towards China [8]. This shift is visually represented by the increase in the percentage of Americans who feel "cold" toward China.  ![American perceptions of China have worsened significantly, with a notable increase in those feeling "cold" towards the country.](image2)

Several factors contribute to these increasingly negative views:

*   **Human Rights Concerns:** Half of Americans consider China's human rights policies a very serious problem for the U.S., marking a 7-point increase since 2020 [6]. This includes widespread concern about the treatment of Uyghurs in Xinjiang, which has been labeled a "genocide" [1]. Many Americans mentioned human rights concerns when they think of China [10]. Some common themes that were brought up included human rights, lack of freedoms, and the genocide of Uyghurs [10].  ![Open-ended responses from Americans reveal significant concerns about human rights, economic issues, and the political system in China.](image3)
*   **Economic Relations:** A majority of Americans (64%) view the economic relationship between the U.S. and China as somewhat or very bad [9]. Concerns include job losses to China and China's growing technological power [6].
*   **Limiting China's Influence:** Nearly half of Americans (48%) believe that limiting China's power and influence should be a top foreign policy priority, a 16-point increase since 2018 [4].
*   **Partisan Divide**: While negative feelings have increased among both Republicans and Democrats, the partisan gap has widened since 2018. Republicans show a much steeper increase in "very cold" feelings towards China compared to Democrats [7].

In summary, American perceptions of China have significantly worsened from 2018 to 2021, driven by concerns over human rights, economic relations, and a growing desire to limit China's global influence.

Americans express substantial concern across a range of issues in the U.S.-China relationship [9]. However, four problems stand out as particularly serious: cyberattacks from China, the loss of U.S. jobs to China, China's growing military power, and China's policies on human rights [9].

![Key concerns of Americans about China from 2020 to 2021, including cyberattacks, human rights, job losses, and military power.](image1)

The sense that certain issues in the bilateral relationship are major problems has grown over the past year alone [10]. Specific concerns, such as cyberattacks, job losses to China, and China's growing technological power, have intensified [10]. Half of Americans now say China's policy on human rights is a *very* serious problem for the U.S., marking a 7-percentage-point increase since last year [10]. Nine-in-ten Americans believe that China does not respect the personal freedoms of its people [10]. The top concerns mentioned by Americans regarding China include human rights, the economy, its political system, and various threats [2, 4].

![Top associations Americans have with China.](image4)

In summary, the key concerns of Americans regarding China are cyberattacks, job losses, China's growing military and technological power, and its human rights policies, with these concerns intensifying over time.

Financial optimism among Latinos has significantly increased since 2008, outpacing the general population [9, 10]. In 2015, 81% of Latinos expected their family's financial situation to improve in the coming year, marking a 14-percentage-point increase since 2008 [10]. In contrast, the share of all Americans sharing this optimistic view rose by only 6 percentage points, reaching 61% during the same period [9].

This trend is visually represented in a graph comparing the optimism levels of Hispanics and the general public from 2004 to 2015. ![Hispanic financial expectations have risen faster than the general population](image5)

Breaking down the data by subgroups reveals that the optimism increase is widespread across different demographics within the Latino community. ![Changes in Financial Optimism](image1). Both U.S.-born and foreign-born Hispanics saw a 14-percentage-point increase in optimism, reaching 81% in each group [6].

Optimism levels also rose among Latino men (+18 percentage points) and Latina women (+11 percentage points) [6]. Additionally, the increase was observed across all age groups, with those aged 18-29 showing a 13-percentage-point rise, and those aged 30-49 and 50-64 each experiencing a 16-percentage-point increase [5]. Educational attainment also played a role, with Latinos who had completed some college education experiencing a 20-percentage-point increase, approximately twice as fast as those with a high school diploma (+9) or less education (+11) [2].

In conclusion, financial optimism among Latinos has risen significantly from 2008 to 2015, exceeding that of the general population, with notable increases across various demographic subgroups.

Hispanics generally hold optimistic views about their children's financial futures [7, 6]. This optimism is influenced by their current financial situation and educational attainment [3, 5].

Hispanics who perceive their current financial situation positively are significantly more likely to believe their family's finances will improve in the coming year [3, 4]. This is visually represented by the stark contrast in expectations between those in "Excellent financial condition" versus those in "Poor financial condition".
![Expectations vary significantly based on current financial condition.](image2)

Educational attainment also plays a role in shaping these expectations [5]. While a majority across all educational levels expect their children to be better off financially, there are nuanced differences:
*   71% of those with less than a high school education.
*   79% of high school graduates.
*	69% of those with some college experience or more [5].
![Financial expectations of Hispanics for their children, by education level.](image5)

Overall, while optimism prevails, it's clear that those currently experiencing financial prosperity and those who have completed high school education are the most confident about their children's financial futures. High school graduates are more optimistic than people with less than a high school education or people with some college experience or more [5].

In conclusion, current financial well-being and educational level significantly impact Hispanics' expectations for their children's financial future, with those in better financial situations and high school graduates being the most optimistic.

From 2000 to 2015, there's a contrast between the improving perceptions of financial well-being among Latinos and the mixed economic indicators, particularly concerning unemployment.

Latinos have expressed increasing optimism about their financial future. The share of Latinos who expect their family finances to improve "a lot" or "some" in the coming year increased from 67% in 2008 and 2011 to 81% in 2015 [7]. This optimism extends to their children's future, with 72% of Hispanic adults expecting their children to be better off financially than themselves [3, 5].
![Better off](image2)

However, this optimism contrasts with some of the economic realities. The Hispanic unemployment rate has improved since the Great Recession, falling from a high of 12.8% in the first quarter of 2010 to 6.4% in the last quarter of 2015 [6].
![Quarterly unemployment rate Hispanic vs. non-Hispanic](image5)
The median household income for Hispanics has stagnated since the Great Recession, remaining at $42,491 in 2014 [1].
![2000 2014](image1)

In summary, while Latinos show increasing optimism about their financial well-being and future prospects, the unemployment trends present a mixed picture, with rates improving but still above pre-recession levels and median household income remaining unchanged.

Hispanics are generally more optimistic about the U.S. economy than other groups [9]. 35% of Hispanics rated the economic conditions as good or excellent in December 2015, compared to only 25% of whites [9]. A significant majority, 72%, of Latino adults believe their children will be financially better off than they are [5].
![72% of Latino adults believe their children will be financially better off than they are](image3)

The Hispanic unemployment rate has improved since the Great Recession, but it remains higher than that of non-Hispanic workers [6]. The Hispanic unemployment rate was 6.4% in the last quarter of 2015, compared with the non-Hispanic unemployment rate during the same time period.
![Quarterly unemployment rate Hispanic vs. non-Hispanic](image5)
The median household income for Hispanics has stagnated since the Great Recession, at $42,491 in 2014 [3].
![Hispanic median household income was $42,500 in 2014](image2)
Hispanic households experienced a large decline in their net worth during and after the recession [3].

In summary, despite a higher unemployment rate than non-Hispanics and economic challenges, Hispanics are more optimistic about the national economic conditions and their children's financial futures, while also showing a larger percentage point improvement in unemployment than the general public since 2011.

Hispanic households have experienced a unique set of economic challenges compared to all U.S. households between 2000 and 2015.

In terms of unemployment, the Hispanic community saw improvements, with rates falling from a high of 12.8% in 2010 to 6.4% in 2015, although this remained higher than the 5% low in 2006 and higher than that for non-Hispanic workers [1].
![Quarterly unemployment rate Hispanic vs. non-Hispanic](image5)

Median household income for Hispanics stagnated after the Great Recession, remaining at $42,491 in 2014 [7]. ![Median Household income for Hispanics](image2)
The Hispanic poverty rate in 2014 was 23.6%, lower than the 2010 peak of 26.5%, but still above pre-recession levels [7].
![Hispanic poverty rate](image2)

Hispanic households experienced the largest percentage decline in net worth through 2009 and continued to fall after the recession, unlike white households [7]. In terms of overall financial well being perceptions, Latino views are more positive than they are in 2004, in contrast to the public's view which is less positive than 2004 [9].
![Latino view of financial situation](image1)

In summary, Hispanic households faced greater economic challenges than U.S. households overall between 2000 and 2015, with higher unemployment rates, stagnating income, higher poverty rates, and significant declines in wealth.

From 2008 to 2015, Latino perceptions of their economic well-being generally increased across most major demographic subgroups [1]. Ratings of personal finances improved among most Latino groups [8].

![Perceptions of personal finances improved between 2008 and 2015 among most Latino demographic subgroups, as illustrated by the significant percentage point increases.](image3)

For instance, positive views of economic well-being rose significantly among both U.S.-born Hispanics (+17 percentage points) and those born in another country (+18 points) [10]. Similar gains were seen among Latino men (+16 percentage points) and Latina women (+18 points) [10]. These positive assessments also increased by double digits among those with less than a high school education (+12 points), high school graduates (+16 points), and those who had attended college (+17 points) [10].

However, views on family income in relation to the cost of living remained relatively unchanged between 2014 and 2015 [4]. In 2015, about half (53%) of Latinos reported that their family income was not keeping up with the cost of living [3].
![In 2015, a little more than half of Hispanic family income did not keep up with living costs.](image1)

In summary, while perceptions of personal financial situations improved significantly among various Latino demographic subgroups between 2008 and 2015, their views on family income relative to the cost of living remained largely static, with about half reporting that their income was not keeping pace with expenses.

Internet usage and device ownership among seniors differ significantly from the general adult population, with notable trends in their daily internet engagement.

Device ownership is one area of difference [10]. While a majority of all adults own smartphones, the percentage is much lower for seniors, especially those over 75 [2].

![Device ownership comparison between all adults and seniors (65+)](image3)

As depicted, smartphone and tablet ownership is notably lower among seniors (65+) compared to all adults.

Internet usage also varies significantly. A smaller proportion of seniors use the internet compared to the general population [6].

![Internet and broadband adoption rates among different age groups of seniors.](image2)

Internet and broadband adoption rates drop significantly around age 75 [6].

However, among seniors who do use the internet, a large majority integrate it into their daily lives [4, 8]. Most senior internet users go online daily or almost daily [4, 8].
![Daily internet usage frequency across different age groups.](image1)

The frequency of daily internet usage is high among those 65 and older, it is less than other age groups [1]. Seniors who own smartphones or have home broadband connections exhibit even higher frequencies of daily internet usage [8].
Social media usage also shows that a segment of online seniors uses social networking sites [9].

![Proportion of seniors using social networking sites (SNS).](image4)

In summary, while seniors have lower rates of internet usage and device ownership compared to the general adult population, those who are online tend to use the internet very frequently, often on a daily basis.

Device ownership among older adults has unique characteristics that correlate with their internet usage patterns. While a significant majority of older adults (77%) own a cell phone, these tend to be basic devices rather than smartphones [5]. Smartphone ownership among older adults is only at 18%, which is significantly lower than the general population [5]. Interestingly, tablet and e-book reader ownership among older adults is on par with smartphone ownership, with 18% owning each, and 27% owning either a tablet or an e-book reader [7].
![Device Ownership among Older Adults](image4)
Despite lower smartphone ownership, a majority of seniors (59%) report using the internet [3]. This is lower than the general population's internet usage rate of 86% [3], as illustrated by the following chart:
![Internet Usage Comparison](image1)
However, those older adults who do use the internet tend to do so frequently. Among older internet users, 71% go online every day or almost every day, and an additional 11% go online three to five times per week [10]. As shown below, a good portion of people in the 65+ age group go online daily.
![Frequency of Internet Use](image2)
In conclusion, while device ownership, particularly of smartphones, is lower among older adults compared to the general population, a majority of seniors do use the internet, and those who do, use it frequently.

Internet adoption among seniors has significantly increased over time. Five years prior to the data collection, only 35% of older adults were internet users, but this figure rose to 59% by the time of the report [4]. This trend is visually represented in a graph showing the increase in internet adoption among seniors compared to all adults. ![Internet adoption over time, seniors vs. all adults](image4)

Despite the increase, usage rates among seniors still trail the general population by a substantial margin, with 86% of all U.S. adults going online [4]. A table details internet and broadband usage among different subgroups of seniors, categorized by age, education, and household income. ![Total for all 65+](image1) For instance, internet usage varies significantly by age, with 74% of those aged 65-69 going online, compared to only 37% of those aged 80 and above [1],  ![Total for all 65+](image1).

Device ownership also differs notably between older adults and the general population. While 55% of all adults own a smartphone, only 18% of seniors do [1], [7]. However, 27% of older adults own a tablet, an e-book reader, or both [5]. A comparison of device ownership is illustrated, highlighting the differences in smartphone and tablet/e-reader ownership between seniors and the general adult population. ![mSmartphone «Tablet or e-reader](image3)

In summary, while internet adoption among seniors has grown over time, it still lags behind the general adult population, with notable differences in device ownership and online activity.

Technology adoption among seniors shows some interesting trends, particularly when comparing device ownership and online social networking habits. While a significant majority of seniors, 59%, report using the internet [2], and the usage rates among senior are increasing steadily [1], there's a notable difference in how they engage with various technologies.

When it comes to devices, tablets and e-readers are as popular as smartphones among older adults, with 18% owning each [10]. In fact, the proportion of seniors owning either a tablet or an e-book reader (27%) is actually *larger* than the proportion owning a smartphone (18%) [10].
![Smartphone «Tablet or e-reader](image1)

However, online social networking usage presents a different picture. 27% of older adults use social networking sites such as Facebook [4, 7].
![Use SNS](image2)
It's means that not every online senior is engaged in social networking, even as device ownership, especially of tablets and e-readers, is relatively common.

In summary, while many seniors own devices like tablets and e-readers, a smaller percentage use social networking sites.

Internet and broadband adoption rates among seniors are increasing, but they still lag behind the national average [5]. Several factors influence these rates, including age, education, and income [3, 8].

As age increases, internet and broadband usage tends to decrease dramatically [3]. For example, 74% of seniors aged 65-69 go online, compared to only 37% of those aged 80 and older. Similarly, broadband adoption is 65% for the 65-69 age group and drops to 21% for those 80 and older. This pattern is visible across multiple digital platforms.
![Age, Education, Income Impact on Tech Adoption](image1)

Education levels have a notable impact. Seniors who are college graduates exhibit significantly higher internet (87%) and broadband (76%) adoption rates compared to those with a high school education or less (40% and 27%, respectively) [10].
![Internet and Broadband Usage Stats by Age, Education, Income](image5)

Income also plays a crucial role [1]. Seniors with higher household incomes show substantially greater adoption rates. Those with an annual income of $75,000 or more have internet and broadband adoption rates of 90% and 82%, respectively. These rates contrast sharply with those of seniors earning less than $30,000 annually, where internet usage is 39% and broadband adoption is only 25% [10].

Overall, while 59% of all seniors (65+) use the internet, this is significantly lower than the 86% usage rate among all U.S. adults [2].
![Internet Usage Comparison: Seniors vs. All Adults](image4)

In summary, internet and broadband adoption among older adults vary significantly based on age, education, and income, with younger, more educated, and wealthier seniors having rates closer to the general population, while older, less educated, and lower-income seniors lag behind.

Internet and broadband adoption rates among seniors show significant variation based on income and education levels [3].

For seniors with an annual household income of $75,000 or more, 90% go online, and 82% have broadband at home [9]. College graduates show similarly high rates, with 87% going online and 76% having broadband [7, 9].
![Internet and broadband adoption rates for seniors based on income and education.](image3)
In contrast, seniors earning less than $30,000 annually have much lower adoption rates, with only 39% going online and 25% having broadband at home [9]. Seniors who have not attended college also exhibit lower rates: 40% go online, and just 27% have broadband at home [9].

Cell phone adoption is widespread among seniors, but smartphone adoption remains relatively low [4, 10].
![Cell phone and smartphone adoption rates by income and education](image5)
Cell phone ownership varies from 92% to 67% and Smartphone adoption varies from 42% to 8%.

In summary, internet, broadband, and smartphone adoption rates are significantly higher among wealthier and more educated seniors, while cell phone ownership is prevalent across all demographic subgroups.

Internet and smartphone adoption rates among older adults show significant variations based on income and education levels, and these rates also differ from overall national trends.

For internet usage, a clear disparity exists. Among older adults aged 65 and above, 59% go online [9]. However, this rate varies significantly across different demographics. For instance, only 39% of those with an annual household income of less than $30,000 use the internet, while the adoption rate is much higher, at 90%, for those with incomes of $75,000 or more [image5]. Similarly, internet usage among those with a high school education or less is 40%, whereas it is 87% for college graduates [image5].

![Broadband at home](image5)

Broadband adoption at home follows similar trends. Overall, 47% of older adults have a broadband connection at home [9]. This rate drops to 25% for those with incomes under $30,000 and rises to 82% for those earning $75,000 or more [image5]. Education also plays a role, with broadband adoption at 27% for those with a high school education or less, compared to 76% for college graduates [image5].

Smartphone ownership, it's significantly lower than cell phone ownership among seniors [5]. Only 18% of seniors own a smartphone, in stark contrast to the 77% who own a cell phone [9, image4]. This is well below the national smartphone adoption rate of 55% [10]. Among older adults with an income of less than $30,000, smartphone ownership is at 8%, but it increases to 42% for those with incomes of $75,000 or more [image4]. Education also affects smartphone ownership, with 10% for high school graduates or less and 35% for college graduates [image4].

![Cell phone Smartphone](image4)

In general, affluent and well-educated seniors are more likely to adopt the internet [1]. Older adults with lower incomes and those who have not attended college are less involved in online life [3]. Tablet computer adoption among senior citizens also differ by income and eduction [image1].

In summary, internet and smartphone adoption rates among older adults are significantly influenced by income and education, with higher income and education levels correlating with higher adoption rates, but these rates are still generally lower than the national averages for all adults.

Internet usage and smartphone ownership among seniors show significant variation based on educational attainment. Seniors with higher educational levels tend to have higher rates of both internet usage and smartphone ownership.

For instance, college graduates (those who completed college) demonstrate significantly higher internet usage compared to those with a high school education or less. Specifically, 87% of college graduates aged 65 and older go online [2], in stark contrast to the 40% of seniors with a high school education or less who use the internet.
![Internet and broadband adoption rates among seniors of different educational backgrounds.](image2)
Similarly, smartphone ownership is much higher among college-educated seniors. Data indicates that 35% of college graduate seniors own a smartphone, compared to just 10% of those with a high school education or less [5].
![Smartphone ownership rates among seniors with different educational levels.](image5)
These figures highlight a clear trend: as the level of education increases among seniors, so does their engagement with digital technology, in terms of both internet usage and smartphone adoption.

In conclusion, internet usage and smartphone ownership are significantly higher among seniors with higher educational backgrounds.

Among seniors, internet and broadband adoption rates, along with cell phone and smartphone ownership, vary significantly based on education and income levels.

For seniors with a college degree, 87% go online, and 76% have broadband at home [3]. This demographic also shows high cell phone ownership at 87%, with 35% owning smartphones ![Cell phone and Smartphone ownership, and broadband adoption of seniors based on education](image2). In contrast, seniors who have not attended college have lower rates: 40% go online, and only 27% have broadband at home [3]. Cell phone ownership in this group is at 70%, with a mere 10% owning smartphones ![Cell phone and Smartphone ownership, and broadband adoption of seniors based on education](image2).

![Broadband adoption of seniors based on income](image3) shows that 90% of seniors with an annual household income of $75,000 or more go online, and 82% have broadband at home [3]. This affluent group also has a high rate of cell phone ownership (92%) and the highest smartphone ownership among seniors at 42% ![Cell phone and Smartphone ownership of seniors based on income](image2). Seniors earning less than $30,000 annually show significantly lower rates: 39% go online, and 25% have broadband at home [3]. Among this lower-income group, 67% own cell phones, but only 8% have smartphones ![Cell phone and Smartphone ownership of seniors based on income](image2).

In summary, higher education and income levels among seniors correlate with higher rates of internet use, broadband adoption, cell phone ownership, and smartphone adoption.

Broadband adoption rates among seniors vary significantly based on educational attainment and household income.

For seniors with an annual household income of $75,000 or more, 82% have broadband at home, compared to just 25% of seniors earning less than $30,000 annually [10]. Similarly, 76% of seniors with a college degree are broadband adopters [2], while only 27% of seniors who have not attended college have broadband at home [10].

These disparities are visually represented in the following chart:

![Broadband at home adoption rates for seniors vary based on income and education, with higher rates for those with higher income and education levels.](image2)

As the image shows, broadband adoption rates increase significantly with both higher income and education levels. College graduates and those in higher income brackets exhibit much higher broadband adoption rates compared to those with lower educational attainment and income [2, 10].

In conclusion, broadband adoption at home among seniors is significantly higher for those with higher educational attainment and household income.

Tablet and e-book reader adoption among seniors is significantly influenced by education level. Seniors who have graduated from college are approximately three times as likely to own both an e-book reader and a tablet compared to seniors who have not attended college [4].

Specifically, the adoption rates for e-book readers and tablets among college graduate seniors are 30% and 31%, respectively.
![Tablet and e-book reader adoption rates vary significantly among seniors based on education level, with college graduates showing the highest adoption rates.](image3)

In terms of broader technology adoption trends, internet usage, in general, has been steadily increasing over the years across all age groups.
![Internet usage by age group, 2000-2012, showing growth in all age groups, especially those over 65.](image2)
The increase of technology adoptions are steadily increasing in recent years [2].

In conclusion, education level significantly impacts the adoption of tablets and e-book readers among seniors, with higher education correlating with higher adoption rates, mirroring general technology adoption trends over time across all age groups.

Educational attainment significantly shapes how workers perceive the impact of technology on their careers. College graduates are more likely to report that technology has made their work more interesting and increased their opportunities for advancement compared to those with a high school diploma or less [10]. For instance, 64% of college graduates find their work more interesting due to technology, compared to only 38% of those with a high school diploma or less [1, 7, 10].
![Made their work more interesting Increased their opportunities for advancement](image1)
Similarly, 53% of college graduates see increased career advancement opportunities, versus 32% of those with a high school diploma or less [7, 10]. This suggests that the benefits of workforce technologies are more likely to accrue to workers with higher levels of formal education [1, 6].

In terms of future expectations for driverless car technology, a significant majority of Americans are aware of the development efforts, and many anticipate widespread adoption in the coming decades [2].
![56 Less than 10 years 10 to less than 50 years 50 to less than 100 years 100+ years Never happen](image2)
Roughly two-thirds of the public predict that most vehicles on the road will be driverless within the next half-century, with 9% expecting this to happen within the next 10 years [2].

In conclusion, higher educational attainment correlates with a more positive perception of workforce technologies, and there is a general expectation that driverless car technology will become widespread within the next 50 years.

Workers with varying levels of educational attainment express pronounced differences in their views of workplace technology [8]. Those with at least a four-year college degree have markedly more positive views compared with those with high school diplomas or less [4]. These differences are most pronounced in the case of office productivity tools such as word processing or spreadsheet software [4].
![Educational level comparison of attitudes toward workplace technologies.](image5)
A significant percentage point difference exists between workers with college degrees (90%) and those with high school diplomas or less (45%) who feel these technologies have had a positive impact on them professionally [4]. The impact of technology, in general, has made their work more interesting [9].
![How technology has changed the work.](image6)
Many Americans anticipate that various automation technologies will make significant inroads in terms of their development and adoption in the coming decades. Fully 94% of Americans have some awareness of the effort to develop driverless vehicles, and roughly two-thirds of the public anticipates that most vehicles on the road will be driverless within the next half-century, with 9% predicting that this will occur in the next 10 years [1].
![Percentage of people who think there will be more driverless cars at a certain time.](image1)

In conclusion, perceptions of workforce technologies' impact vary significantly by education level, with college graduates generally having more positive views, while a substantial majority of Americans anticipate the widespread adoption of driverless cars within the next 50 years.

Americans anticipate significant changes from automation technologies, particularly with driverless vehicles [5]. Most of the public expects that the majority of vehicles on the road will be driverless within the next 50 years, with a small percentage predicting this will happen within the next decade [6].
![Most believe that driverless cars will be commonplace within 50 years.](image2)
This expectation contrasts with the current experiences of workers, where the impact of technology is viewed with mixed feelings [1]. Many workers have a positive view of technologies like word processing and smartphones [4].
![Impact of various technologies on workers' own jobs and careers.](image1)
However, a substantial number perceive existing technologies as damaging or neutral to their career prospects [1]. While technologies such as word processing and smartphones are seen to have made work more interesting, perceptions vary about whether technology has increased career advancement opportunities [7].
![Impact of technology on workers' opportunities for advancement.](image4)
The impact is also seen to differ based on educational levels, with those having higher education more likely to benefit [8]. Overall, current experiences with workforce technology have had diverse impacts [8], contrasting with the broad expectations for future technologies like driverless vehicles.

In conclusion, perceptions differ as future expectations for driverless vehicles are generally anticipated to have significant impacts, while current experiences with various technologies show a mix of positive, negative, and neutral impacts on workers' careers.

Workers with higher levels of education tend to have more positive views of workplace technologies [1, 3]. This is particularly evident when comparing college graduates with those who have high school diplomas or less.

In terms of job interest, a significant majority of college graduates (64%) report that technology has made their work more interesting, compared to only 38% of workers with high school diplomas or less [2].  This difference is illustrated in the following chart:
![Made their work more interesting, Increased their opportunities for advancement](image3)

For career opportunities, 53% of college graduates believe technology has increased their opportunities for advancement, while only 32% of workers with high school diplomas or less share this view [2]. Workers with some college education typically fall between these two groups, expressing more positive views than those with no college experience, but less positive views than college graduates [4]. The chart above depicts the opinions from different education level [image3].
When looking at specific technologies, these educational differences persist. For instance, 90% of college graduates report a positive impact from word processing or spreadsheet software, compared to just 45% of those with high school diplomas or less [9].
![Word processing or spreadsheet software, Smartphones, Email or social media, Software that manages daily schedules, Customer self-service technologies, Industrial robots](image4)

In general, roughly half (53%) of all workers feel that technology has made their work more interesting [5], and 46% feel it has increased their career advancement opportunities [5].
![Less interesting More interesting Had no impact either way](image2)
![Decreased their Increased their opportunities opportunities Had no impact either way](image1)
The impact of technology on how demanding the job is can be seen in the chart [image5].
![Less demanding More demanding Had no impact either way](image5)

In conclusion, perceptions of workplace technologies vary significantly by education level, with college graduates reporting more positive impacts on job interest and career opportunities compared to workers with less education.

Workers with higher levels of education are more likely to view technology as a positive influence that enhances their jobs and career prospects [7, 8]. Specifically, college graduates are much more likely than those with a high school diploma or less to state that technology has made their work more interesting (64% vs. 38%) [1].  

![Workers with higher levels of education are more inclined to believe tech has enhanced opportunities and made their jobs more captivating.](image5)

This trend is further illustrated by data comparing the perceptions of workers with different educational backgrounds [2, 3]. A significant portion of workers with at least a four-year college degree reported positive impacts from various technologies on their jobs, compared to those with high school diplomas or less [9].

![Positive impact of work technologies based on different educational backgrounds](image3)

Furthermore, college graduates are more likely to report that technology has increased their opportunities for career advancement (53% vs. 32%) [1]. In contrast, a substantial percentage of workers with high school diplomas or less (24%) feel that none of the six technologies surveyed has positively impacted their jobs or careers, compared to just 2% of college graduates [5, 9].

Educational attainment levels significantly influence the perceived impact of technologies on work, with higher education correlating with a more positive outlook on technology's role in making work more interesting and increasing advancement opportunities.

Workers with higher levels of education tend to have more positive views of how technology impacts their careers [6, 8]. College graduates are significantly more likely than those with a high school diploma or less to report that technology has made their work more interesting (64% vs. 38%) and increased their opportunities for career advancement (53% vs. 32%) [9].
![Educational levels impact perceptions of technology's effects on job opportunities and work interest.](image3)
This difference is visualized that shows the percentages for each education level regarding whether technology made their work more interesting or increased opportunities [9].
![Perceptions of technology's effects on job opportunities.](image4)
In contrast, a substantial portion of workers with high school diplomas or less feel that technology has not significantly impacted their careers, either positively or negatively [7]. Specifically, 44% of workers with a high school education or less say their professional lives have not been affected one way or the other by word processing or spreadsheet software, and 35% say the same about email or social media [7]. There is a pronounced difference between college graduates (90%) and those with high school diplomas or less (45%) who believe these technologies have positively impacted them professionally. [10].
![Technology has varying effects on job interest.](image5)
These differences extend to various technologies, including email, social media, smartphones, and scheduling software, with gaps of 20 percentage points or more between the two groups [10].
![Technological impact on different educational groups.](image1)

In conclusion, educational attainment significantly influences perceptions of technology in the workplace, with higher education levels correlating with more positive views on technology's impact on job opportunities and work interest.

Americans who have heard a lot about the concept of robots and computers performing many human jobs are more likely to find the concept extremely realistic. Specifically, 48% of those highly aware find it extremely realistic [3], as shown in the breakdown of awareness levels.

![Heard a lot ™ Heard a little Heard nothing](image3)

Despite this realism, their enthusiasm doesn't necessarily negate their worries. While 47% of those who have heard a lot express some level of enthusiasm about machines potentially doing many jobs currently done by humans [7], a significant 76% in the same group also express worry about this future [9].

The expected outcomes of widespread automation lean more towards the negative. A majority, 76%, anticipate that it will worsen economic inequality [10]. The expectation for job creation is low, with only 25% believing that the economy will create many new, well-paying jobs for humans in such a scenario [1]. This sentiment is detailed in a chart showing expected outcomes:

![POSSIBLE NEGATIVE OUTCOMES No, not likely _Yes, likely](image4)

In summary, increased awareness of automation among Americans correlates with a higher perception of its realism and some enthusiasm, but it also brings substantial worry, particularly about economic inequality and job prospects.

Public opinion on policies related to workforce automation shows some notable differences between Democrats and Republicans, particularly when it comes to government intervention. Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents are significantly more supportive of a universal basic income (77% favor) compared to Republicans and Republican-leaning independents (38% favor) [2, 9].
![All citizens guaranteed a basic income](image3)
A similar trend is observed for a national service program, favored by 66% of Democrats versus 46% of Republicans [2, 9].

However, there is strong bipartisan support for limiting machines to performing dangerous and dirty jobs [9]. The vast majority of Americans, regardless of political affiliation, favor this policy [6].
![Machines do dangerous or unhealthy jobs only](image3)
This is further supported by the fact that 85% of Americans favor this type of policy, with 47% strongly favoring it [6]. Opposition to government job and income support is stronger than the idea that machines should do dangerous jobs [7]. There are also fairly comparable views regarding the limitation of the job that machines should replace [4, 9].
![Should be limits on # of jobs businesses can replace with machines, even if they are better and cheaper than humans](image4)
In general, a large majority of Americans support limiting machines to dangerous or unhealthy jobs, while Democrats show significantly higher support for government interventions like universal basic income and national service programs compared to Republicans.

Political affiliation significantly influences opinions on the government's obligation to assist workers displaced by automation. Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents are much more likely to believe the government has an obligation to care for displaced workers, even if it means higher taxes [3]. Approximately 65% of Democrats support this view, while a nearly identical share (68%) of Republicans believe individuals should be responsible for their own financial well-being [3].
![Govt has obligationto _ Individuals have obligation take care of displaced __ to care for own well-being, workers, even ifit means even if machines have raising taxes substantially already taken many jobs](image4)

However, views on limiting the number of jobs businesses can replace with machines are less divided along partisan lines. A slight majority of Republicans (54%) believe there should be limits on automation, which is only slightly less than the 60% of Democrats who hold the same view [7].
![Should be limits on # of jobs —_ Businesses are justified in businesses can replace with _ replacing human workers machines, even if they are better _if machines can do job and cheaper than humans better and at lower cost](image4)

Education levels also play a role, particularly regarding limits on automation. Individuals with lower levels of educational attainment are more supportive of limiting the number of jobs businesses can automate [10]. For instance, 70% of those with a high school diploma or less support such limits, compared to only 41% of those with a four-year college degree [10]. There is also some support to create service program to pay for the displaced humans to perform jobs [9].
![If the govt created a national service program that would pay people to perform tasks](image1)

In summary, Democrats are more likely than Republicans to support government intervention for displaced workers, while individuals with lower education levels are more likely to support limits on job automation, regardless of political affiliation.

Americans' views on policies related to workforce automation and job displacement are significantly influenced by their political affiliations. Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents are notably more supportive of a universal basic income, with 77% in favor compared to just 38% of Republicans and Republican-leaning independents [1, 10]. A similar trend is observed for a national service program, favored by 66% of Democrats versus 46% of Republicans [1, 10].
![Democrats are more supportive of certain policies than Republicans.](image4)
However, there is more bipartisan agreement on limiting machines to dangerous and dirty jobs, and there are comparable levels of support for placing general limits on the number of jobs businesses can replace with robots or computers (60% of Democrats and 54% of Republicans) [1, 10].
![Support and Opposition levels of different groups for automation scenarios.](image2)
There is a clear partisan divide regarding the government's obligation to care for workers displaced by automation [4]. 65% of Democrats believe the government has an obligation to take care of displaced workers, even if it means higher taxes [4]. Conversely, 68% of Republicans believe individuals should be responsible for their own financial well-being, even if jobs are widely automated [4].

![The opinions of Americans on automation based on their level of education.](image3)

In summary, political affiliation significantly impacts views on policies related to workforce automation, with Democrats generally favoring government intervention and support programs, while Republicans emphasize individual responsibility.

Attitudes towards workforce automation and the perceived impact of technology vary significantly across different age groups and education levels. Younger workers, particularly those aged 18-24, are more likely to have been personally impacted by workforce automation [2].
![U.S. adults aged 18-24 are most likely to report job loss or wage reduction due to automation.](image3)
Workers with higher levels of education tend to have a more positive outlook on workplace technologies [3]. College graduates are more likely to report that technology has made their work more interesting and increased their opportunities for advancement [7].
![Workers with a college degree or higher education more often report that technology has made their work more interesting and increased career advancement opportunities.](image4)
In contrast, those without a college education are less likely to view workforce technologies positively [5, 10]. A significant portion of workers with high school diplomas or less feel that technology has not made their jobs more interesting or increased career opportunities [10]. The benefits of technological tools often accrue to workers with higher levels of formal education [1].
![Impact of various technologies on workers' jobs and careers.](image1)
The survey indicates educational differences in how technology affects workers' careers [8].

In summary, younger workers and those with lower educational attainment are more likely to experience negative impacts from workforce automation, while those with higher education levels generally perceive technology as a positive influence on their careers.

Workers have mixed views about how workforce technologies have impacted their jobs and careers [3, 8]. A significant portion views technology as a largely positive influence, making their work more interesting and providing opportunities for career advancement, but a substantial share views it negatively [4].

The benefits of these tools are most likely to accrue to workers with high levels of formal educational attainment [4]. College graduates are substantially more likely to say that technology has made their work more interesting and increased their opportunities for career advancement [1]. This is illustrated by the fact that 64% of college graduates believe technology has made their work more interesting, compared to 38% of those with a high school diploma or less. Similarly, 53% of college graduates say technology has increased their career advancement opportunities, versus 32% of those with a high school diploma or less [9].
![Made their work more interesting and Increased their opportunities for advancement](image4)
Workers who have not attended college are much less likely to view today’s workforce technologies in such a positive light [6].

The survey shows different impacts of various workforce technologies [7]. It shows a breakdown of how different technologies have impacted workers, with word processing or spreadsheet software and smartphones having a mostly positive impact, while industrial robots have had a more neutral effect [10].
![A negative, positive and No impact either way](image5)
The answer is perceptions of the impact of workforce automation and technology vary significantly across different demographics, with educational attainment being a key factor influencing whether the impact is viewed positively or negatively.

Workers with higher levels of education are more likely to report that technology has increased opportunities and made their jobs more interesting [6]. Specifically, 64% of college graduates believe technology has made their work more interesting, compared to 38% of workers with high school diplomas or less [7].
![Made their work more interesting Increased their opportunities for advancement](image1)
A similar trend is observed for career advancement, with 54% of college graduates reporting that technology has increased their opportunities, while only 32% of those with a high school diploma or less feel the same [7].

The survey also examined the impact of six specific workforce technologies, finding that workers with college degrees were much more likely than those without a college education to say that each had a positive effect on their jobs or careers [5].
![A positive impact](image5)
The technologies included word processing and spreadsheet software, smartphones, email and social media, schedule management software, customer self-service technologies, and industrial robots [5, 9].

In general, workers express more positive than negative views about technology's effect, with about half indicating technology made their work more interesting and increased career advancement opportunities [2].
![More interesting Had no impact either way](image2)
![Increased their opportunities](image3)
However, a notable proportion of workers, especially those with lower education levels, do not share this positive outlook [8].

In summary, education level significantly influences workers' perceptions of technology's impact, with college-educated workers more likely to view technology as positively affecting job interest and advancement opportunities, particularly in relation to specific technologies like software and communication tools.

Social media evokes a range of emotional responses, and these reactions vary across different age groups [9]. The most commonly reported emotion is amusement, with 88% of users indicating they encounter content that makes them feel this way [7]. 44% of users frequently experience amusement [7].
![Amused](image3)
Younger adults, aged 18-29, are more likely to report feeling amused, with 54% frequently seeing content that sparks this emotion [2].
![Ages 65+ 50-64 30-49 18-29](image2)
However, they are also more prone to feeling lonely, with 15% of this age group frequently experiencing loneliness, compared to just 4% of those 50 and older [5]. Older adults, aged 65 and older, report similar frequencies of feeling amused (30%) and angry (24%) [5]. Across all age groups, a significant portion of users (25%) frequently encounter content that makes them feel angry [6]. Moreover, users often encounter overly dramatic or exaggerated posts (58%) and people making accusations without having all the facts (59%) [2].
![Posts that are overly dramatic](image1)

In summary, while amusement is the most frequently experienced emotion across all users, younger adults are more likely to feel amused but also lonely, whereas older adults experience amusement and anger with comparable frequency.

Younger adults, aged 18-29, are more likely to frequently encounter content that amuses them (54%) than makes them feel angry (27%) [7]. However, they are also more prone to feeling lonely (15%) compared to older adults aged 30-49 (7%) and those 50 and older (4%) [1].
