Users aged 65 and older experience amusement (30%) and anger (24%) with more comparable frequency [7]. Across all age groups, a significant portion of users frequently encounter content that makes them feel angry [1].

In terms of content, a majority of social media users frequently see posts that are overly dramatic or exaggerated (58%) and people making accusations or starting arguments without having all the facts (59%) [5].

Different age groups experience a range of emotions on social media, with younger users more likely to feel amused but also lonely, while older users experience amusement and anger more equally, and common types of content encountered include dramatic posts and unfounded accusations.

Different age groups exhibit varied emotional responses to social media content. Regarding gender differences, men (29%) are slightly more likely than women (19%) to encounter mean or bullying content, while women are more inclined to see kind or supportive behavior [2]. However, majorities of both men (52%) and women (56%) report seeing an equal mix of supportive and bullying behaviors [2]. ![People being People being kind or mean or bullying supportive Equal mix of both Total People trying People trying to to point out be deceptive inaccurate info Equal mix of both Total 17 BER a](image4)

As for the types of content frequently encountered, a majority of social media users report seeing posts that are overly dramatic or exaggerated (58%) and people making accusations or starting arguments without having all the facts (59%) [4].

In conclusion, younger social media users are more frequently amused but also more prone to loneliness, while older users experience a mix of amusement and anger; men are more likely to encounter negative behaviors, whereas women see a more balanced mix, and users of all ages and genders commonly encounter dramatic content and premature accusations.

Different age groups experience a range of emotions on social media, with younger users (18-29) reporting higher frequencies of feeling amused, connected, inspired, depressed, and lonely compared to older users (65+) [4]. For instance, 54% of users aged 18-29 frequently feel amused, while only 30% of those aged 65+ report the same. Similarly, 27% of the 18-29 age group frequently feel angry, a sentiment shared by 23% of users aged 65+ [4].
![Feelings that social media users frequently have, by age group](image4)

As for behaviors, a majority of social media users (54%) say they typically encounter an equal mix of people being kind or supportive and people being mean or bullying [8]. However, men are slightly more likely (29%) than women (19%) to report seeing more mean or bullying behavior than kind behavior [10].
![Breakdown of kind and supportive vs. mean and bullying behaviors encountered on social media](image3)

Regarding the types of posts frequently encountered, 58% of users report seeing posts that are overly dramatic or exaggerated, and 59% frequently see people making accusations or starting arguments without having all the facts [9]. Posts that teach users something useful, and those that are deceptively about something else, are also frequent [9].

![The two most frequent types of content of the four are those that are overly dramatic or those that start arguments without facts.](image5)

In conclusion, younger users report a wider range of emotions on social media more frequently than older users, men are more likely to encounter bullying behavior, and the most common types of posts are dramatic, argumentative, or misleading.

Men are more likely than women to perceive certain negative behaviors on social media. Specifically, a larger share of men (29%) than women (19%) report more often seeing people being mean or bullying rather than kind [10].
![People being mean or bullying](image1)
Similarly, men are about twice as likely as women to say they more often see people being deceptive on social media (24% vs. 13%) [5]. However, majorities of both men (58%) and women (67%) see an equal mix of deceptiveness and attempts to correct misinformation [5].

In terms of encountering specific types of content, a majority of social media users frequently see posts that are overly dramatic or exaggerated (58%) [3, 7].
![Posts that are overly dramatic or exaggerated](image4)
This suggests that such content is prevalent on social media, and it may contribute to the perceptions of negativity that differ between men and women.

In conclusion, men are more likely to report seeing bullying and deceptive behaviors, while both men and women frequently encounter dramatic or exaggerated content on social media.

There are notable differences in how men and women perceive content and behavior on social media platforms. Men are more likely to encounter mean or bullying content [4], with 29% of men versus 19% of women reporting they more often see such behavior [4]. A similar trend appears with deceptive content, as men are about twice as likely as women (24% vs. 13%) to say they more often see people being deceptive on social media [10].

![People being People being kind or mean or bullying supportive Equal mix of both Total](image2)

Women, conversely, are more inclined to see kind or supportive behavior, although the majority of both genders observe a mix of both supportive and bullying actions [4].

![Posts that are overly dramatic or exaggerated](image4)

These trends impact how social media can tailor their services. A majority of users find it acceptable for platforms to use data to recommend local events, and this sentiment is consistent across age groups [3, 6].

![Recommend events in their area](image1)

However, the acceptability varies for other uses of data. For instance, while younger users (18-49) generally find it acceptable for platforms to recommend people they might know, older users (65+) largely disagree [9].
The acceptability of social media platforms tailoring recommendations is also reflected in users' views on seeing advertisements. 

In conclusion, men are more likely to report seeing negative behaviors such as bullying and deception, while women are more likely to report seeing positive interactions.

User comfort with social media companies using their personal data is heavily dependent on how that data is used [7, 8]. There are significant differences in how various age groups perceive the acceptability of these practices.

A majority of users across different age groups find it acceptable for social media sites to use their data to recommend events in their area [3]. For example, 80% of users aged 18-29, 78% of those aged 30-49, 72% of those aged 50-64, and 67% of users aged 65+ find it acceptable. ![Recommend events in their area](image1)

However, older users are much less accepting of social media sites using their data for other reasons, especially when it comes to recommending other people they might know [10]. While 66% of users aged 18-49 find it acceptable for platforms to use their data to recommend connections, only 36% of users aged 65 and older agree [10]. ![Recommend someone they might want to know](image1)

There is also a notable difference in opinion when it comes to using data to show advertisements for products or services. Nearly six-in-ten users ages 18 to 49 think it is acceptable, whereas, only 39% of users 65+ share the same.  ![Show them ads for products and services](image1)

Across all age groups, users are wary of their data being used for political messaging [9]. The percentages of users who find it acceptable to show messages from political campaigns are relatively low across all age groups: 40% for 18-29, 38% for 30-49, 35% for 50-64, and 31% for 65+ [image1]. ![Show them messages from political campaigns](image1)

In summary, different age groups vary significantly in their comfort levels regarding social media platforms using their data, with older users generally being more cautious, particularly about recommendations and advertisements, while most users across age groups are comfortable with data use for local event recommendations but not for political messaging.

Public perceptions of automated decision-making systems vary significantly based on the context of their application, particularly in terms of perceived fairness and effectiveness [6].

One notable example is the contrast between public attitudes toward criminal risk scores and personal finance scores. While similar percentages of the population believe these systems are effective (49% for criminal risk and 54% for personal finance), there's a considerable difference in perceived fairness [1]. Half of Americans (50%) think the criminal risk score is fair to those up for parole, but only 32% believe the personal finance score is fair to consumers [1]. This is a 22-percentage-point difference [8].
![Automated scoring of people up for parole](image4)

The perceived fairness and effectiveness often go hand in hand. However, public views on the acceptability differ greatly based on the system in question [4].
![programs to make decisions without human bias](image1)
This illustrates that while a majority of Americans (58%) believe that computer programs will always show some amount of human bias, some are more worried about algorithmic decision making than others [6]. A significant majority find the personal finance score and video job analysis algorithms unacceptable (68% and 67%, respectively) [9].
![% of U.S. adults who say itis__ for companies to use automated personal finance scores](image2)

These perceptions imply that public trust in automated systems is not solely dependent on their effectiveness, but heavily influenced by concerns about fairness, potential biases, and the specific context in which they are applied [6].

In conclusion, perceptions of fairness and effectiveness in automated systems vary widely depending on the application, with significant implications for public trust, which is heavily influenced by context-specific concerns about fairness and bias.

Public perception of the ethical standards of top Trump administration officials is notably low compared to previous administrations, with views dating back to the 1980s [1, 7]. This is visually represented in data comparing administrations from Reagan to Trump.
![Public ratings of the ethical standards of top administration officials.](image1)

A significant majority of the public (58%) reports trusting what Trump says less than they trusted previous presidents [9]. This distrust has increased since April 2017 [5]. The breakdown by political affiliation reveals a stark partisan divide.

![% who say they trust what Donald Trump says ___ than they trusted what previous presidents said](image4)

Most Democrats and Democratic leaners (94%) trust Trump's statements less than those of previous presidents [2]. Conversely, a majority of Republicans and Republican leaners (58%) trust Trump's statements more than those of previous presidents [6].

The ethical standards of top administration officials are also viewed differently across party lines. A substantial 76% of Republicans and Republican leaners rate the ethical standards of these officials as excellent or good [10]. Only $16\%$ say they are "excellent" [10].
$90\%$ of Democrats and Democratic leaners, saying that ethical standards of top Trump administration officials are not good or poor (with $67\%$ saying they are "poor") [10].

In conclusion, perceptions of Trump's ethical standards and trustworthiness are significantly lower compared to previous presidents, with a deep partisan divide where Democrats overwhelmingly distrust him and Republicans largely trust him more than previous presidents.

Public trust in President Trump's statements is notably lower than that of previous presidents [9]. A majority, 58%, report trusting Trump's statements less than those of his predecessors [10]. This sentiment is particularly strong among Democrats, with 94% expressing less trust in Trump compared to previous presidents. ![Trust levels in Trump compared to previous presidents, broken down by party affiliation.](image3)

Conversely, among Republicans, a majority (58%) trust Trump's statements more than those of previous presidents, while a smaller percentage (15%) trust his rhetoric less [8].

The perception of whether Trump will be a successful president is much more definitive compared to past administrations at similar points in their terms. Fewer people believe it is too early to judge Trump's success than they did for Presidents Obama, Bush, or Clinton [6].
![Public opinion on whether Trump has been a successful president.](image2)

There is wide agreement (64%) that Trump has a responsibility to release his tax returns, a view held by nearly all Democrats (91%) and a significant minority of Republicans (32%) [3]. Additionally, views of the ethical standards of Trump administration officials are at record lows compared to previous administrations, often even lower than during times of specific ethical controversies in those administrations [2, 4]. The public generally views Trump's impact on the economy positively, with 40% believing his policies have improved economic conditions [1].
![Public opinion on whether Trump's policies have improved economic conditions.](image4)

Public perceptions of Trump’s responsibilities and trustworthiness are significantly lower than those of previous presidents, with a strong partisan divide influencing these views.

Public perception of Donald Trump's presidency reveals significant partisan divisions and contrasts with previous administrations.

Ethical standards of top Trump administration officials are viewed very differently depending on political affiliation [10]. A significant majority of Republicans and Republican leaners (76%) rate these standards as excellent or good, while an overwhelming majority of Democrats and Democratic leaners (90%) rate them as not good or poor [10]. These views are notably lower than those of officials in the previous five administrations [7].
![Views of Trump's administration officials compared to officials of previous administrations.](image1)

The economic impact of Trump's policies is also viewed through a partisan lens. A majority of Republicans (79%) believe his policies have improved economic conditions, a figure that has increased since 2017 [9]. Conversely, Democrats have become more negative, with 46% saying his policies have worsened conditions [9].
![Partisan views of Trump’s economic policies between 2017 and 2019.](image4)

Regarding long-term success, 65% of Republicans predict Trump will be a successful president [3]. Democrats, on the other hand, largely anticipate an unsuccessful presidency (80%) [5]. This contrasts with views on previous presidents, where, at similar points in their presidencies, more people, including those from opposing parties, were willing to say it was "too early to tell" [5, 6].
![Long-term outlook of Trump, Obama, Bush and Clinton's presidencies.](image5)

Overall, compared to his three most recent predecessors, there is less uncertainty about Trump's success, and a greater divide. While 47% said it was too early to tell whether Obama would be successful at a comparable point, only 23% say the same about Trump [5].
![Predictions of the success of several presidents.](image3)

In summary, perceptions of Trump's presidency are deeply polarized along party lines, with Republicans generally holding positive views on his economic impact and long-term success, while Democrats view his ethical standards and overall presidency negatively, a contrast more pronounced than with previous administrations.

Views on whether Donald Trump will be a successful president are deeply divided along party lines, a pattern that has become more pronounced over time [3].

Republicans are optimistic, with 65% believing Trump will be successful in the long run [1]. This is similar to Republican views of Bush in 2003, when 69% thought he would be successful [10].
![Republicans optimistic about Trump's success, similar to Bush in 2003](image1)

Democrats, on the other hand, are overwhelmingly negative, with 80% predicting Trump will be unsuccessful [5]. This contrasts sharply with the more uncertain views Democrats held about Bush in 2003, where only 37% believed he would be unsuccessful [10].

Compared to his predecessors, fewer people say it is "too early to tell" about Trump's success [6]. At similar points in their presidencies, a much larger share of the public was undecided about Obama (47%), Bush (38%), and Clinton (43%) [4]. The percentage of Americans who currently believe Trump will be unsuccessful (47%) is significantly higher than those who held similar views about his predecessors at comparable stages [9].
![Fewer people say it is "too early to tell" about Trump's success compared to predecessors](image3)

In conclusion, perceptions of Trump's presidency are highly polarized, with a larger share of the public holding negative views compared to his predecessors, and fewer remaining undecided.

Public opinion regarding Donald Trump's potential success as president is sharply divided along partisan lines. A significant majority of Republicans and Republican-leaning independents (65%) believe that Trump will be a successful president in the long run [6]. Democrats and Democratic leaners hold an opposing view, with a large majority (80%) predicting that Trump will be an unsuccessful president [3].
![Predictions on Trump's Success](image3)

These partisan differences in expectations about Trump's presidency are also reflected in the views of the Mueller investigation [4]. Democrats express high confidence in the fairness of Mueller’s investigation. About seven-in-ten Democrats (72%) are at least somewhat confident in the fairness of Mueller’s investigation [7]. Republicans are far less confident, with a majority (58%) saying they are not too or not at all confident in Mueller [7].
![Confidence in Mueller's Investigation](image4)

Overall, 55% of the public expresses confidence in Mueller's investigation [8], a figure that has remained relatively stable over time [5]. However, confidence in Trump’s handling of the investigation is lower [10]. Democrats overwhelmingly lack confidence in Trump’s handling of the matter (92%) [9]. In contrast, 75% of Republicans express confidence in Trump's handling of the inquiry [9].

In conclusion, perceptions of Trump's potential success are highly polarized, with Republicans largely optimistic and Democrats largely pessimistic, and these views correlate with differing levels of confidence in the Mueller investigation.

Public perception of local job availability is currently the most positive it has been in decades [9]. Currently, a majority of both Republicans (71%) and Democrats (53%) believe there are plenty of jobs available locally [6]. This represents a rise in positive views on job availability since 2017, which aligns with a generally more positive outlook on the economy during this period [10].

![Perceptions of job availability among different political affiliations.](image1)

Views on local job opportunities are among the most positive in the last two decades for both parties [5]. The trend since 2001 shows an overall increase, reaching the highest point in recent years.

![Trend of job availability perceptions from 2001 to 2019.](image2)

However, there's a notable partisan gap in these perceptions [2]. Republicans are consistently more likely than Democrats to rate their personal financial situation positively [7] and there is sizable partisan gap in views of job availability. [2].

![Views of the availability of jobs.](image3)

Although a majority in both parties see jobs as available, the perception differs when considering "good jobs" [4], with a distinction between the availability of jobs and "good jobs" [8].

![Views of the availability of good jobs.](image4)

In summary, perceptions of economic conditions and job availability are generally positive but differ significantly between Republicans and Democrats, with Republicans consistently holding a more optimistic view.

Public perception of job availability has become more positive in recent years, with a majority believing there are plenty of jobs available locally [6, 7]. This sentiment is shared by both Republicans and Democrats, although a partisan gap exists [2, 10].

Currently, 71% of Republicans and 53% of Democrats believe there are plenty of jobs available in their communities [10]. This represents a notable increase in positive views for both parties compared to October 2017 [3, 10]. The general trend indicates views on local job availability are most positive as at any point in the last two decades [3].
![Perceptions of job availability have become more positive over time for both parties.](image3)

The difference between Republican and Democratic views has fluctuated.
![Views of job availability over time show variations between parties and overall trends.](image1)

In general, Republicans consistently show more positive views.
![Job availability trend](image4)
This image specifically highlights how Republicans and Republican-leaning individuals have maintained more positive views of economic conditions since Trump's election [9]. Although there's also a similar trend, perceptions about availability of "good jobs" don't reach majority.
![Most do not think there are plenty of good jobs available.](image2)

Perceptions of job availability differ between political affiliations, with Republicans generally holding more positive views than Democrats, and these perceptions have become increasingly positive over time for both parties.

Americans' views on Wall Street's impact on the economy are divided along partisan lines, with Republicans generally more positive than Democrats [8]. Nearly half of Americans (46%) believe that Wall Street helps the U.S. economy more than it hurts, while 39% believe the opposite [6].

![70 WT OU eee](image3)

Specifically, a majority of Republicans (55%) say Wall Street helps the economy more than it hurts [1], and this is visually supported by data showing a clear distinction between Republican and Democrat leaning individuals [image3]. Democrats, however, are more divided, with similar proportions saying Wall Street hurts (46%) as say it helps (41%) the economy [7].

![G.H.W. Clinton G.W. Bush Obama Trump](image2)

General satisfaction with the state of the nation has fluctuated over time, reaching low points during recent years. Public dissatisfaction was notably high, with 70% of Americans expressing dissatisfaction with the way things were going in the country [3, 5], that is clearly showing in a visual representation of satisfaction levels over the years, from 1990 to 2019 [image1]. A significant partisan divide exists, Only 8% of Democrats expressed satisfaction, in stark contrast to earlier periods [2, 10]. Republican satisfaction, while higher, has also seen declines [9].

![7o Who say they are with the way things are going in this country today](image1)

In summary, Republicans are more likely to view Wall Street positively, while Democrats are divided, and overall national satisfaction is low, with significant partisan differences.

The trend of public satisfaction with the state of the nation has generally been low from 1990 to 2019. In 2019, 70% of Americans reported being dissatisfied with the way things are going in the country, while only about 26% said they were satisfied [1, 2]. This dissatisfaction has been increasing, up 9 percentage points since September [10].
![Public dissatisfaction with the state of the nation is higher than at any point in the past year](image2)
Public satisfaction is deeply divided along partisan lines. As of 2019, only 8% of Democrats expressed satisfaction with the state of the nation, a figure that has not exceeded 16% during Trump's presidency [6, 4]. Republican satisfaction, while higher, has seen fluctuations. It had dropped to 47%, which is the lowest GOP satisfaction rating since late 2017 [5]. The graphic illustrates the fluctuating levels of satisfaction among Republicans and Democrats from 1990 to 2019.
![G.H.W. Bush, Clinton, G.W. Bush, Obama, Trump](image5)
Views on Wall Street's impact on the economy are also divided by political affiliation. Republicans are more likely to believe that Wall Street helps the economy more than it hurts it (55% vs. 31%) [7]. Democrats are more divided, with 46% saying Wall Street does more to hurt the economy and 41% saying it does more to help [3].
![Wall Street effect by party division](image4)
In Summary, public satisfaction levels have remained low from 1990 to 2019, marked by a significant partisan divide, especially concerning views on Wall Street's impact on the economy.

Public confidence in Trump's ability to make good appointments to the federal courts differs significantly between Republicans and Democrats. A majority of Americans express doubt in President Trump's ability to separate his business interests from his presidential decisions. Only about 28% are very confident, and another 13% are somewhat confident that he keeps these interests separate [4]. A significant portion, 41%, are not at all confident [4].

This skepticism is particularly pronounced among Democrats. Nearly 70% are not at all confident, and another 20% are not too confident in Trump's ability to keep his business interests and presidential decisions separate [2]. Liberal Democrats are even more skeptical, with 83% expressing no confidence at all [2].
![Not at all confident that Trump keeps his own business interests separate from the decisions he makes as president](image3)

In contrast, most Republicans (55% very, 23% somewhat) are confident that Trump keeps his business interests separate from his decision-making [10]. Conservative Republicans (66%) are much more likely to express strong confidence than moderate and liberal Republicans (39%) [10].

Regarding the release of tax returns, the public is largely in favor of transparency, with 64% saying Trump has a responsibility to release his tax returns [8].
![Responsibility to release his tax return.](image4)
However, most Republicans (64%) do not believe Trump has a responsibility to release his tax returns, while only 32% say he does [3].

In conclusion, confidence levels in Trump's ability to separate business interests from presidential decisions vary significantly by political affiliation, with Democrats largely skeptical and Republicans mostly confident, while a majority of the public, but a minority of Republicans believe he should release his tax returns.

Partisan divides significantly affect perceptions of the COVID-19 response and institutional trust. Republicans and Democrats differ on the U.S.'s response compared to other wealthy nations, with a minority of Republicans (22%) saying the U.S. has been more effective [1], as depicted in the chart showing the divergent views between Republicans and Democrats regarding the effectiveness of the U.S. response in comparison to other wealthy nations.  ![Americans largely view the U.S. COVID-19 response as less effective than other wealthy nations.](image1)

Democrats overwhelmingly (87%) believe the U.S. response has been less effective [1]. Views on the response from various institutions also differ along party lines. While hospitals receive positive views across party lines, significant differences exist for other officials [5].
![Positive views of hospitals’ response to COVID-19 cross party lines; wider differences on other officials, Trump](image2)

Specifically, Democrats are more likely than Republicans to give positive ratings to public health officials, state, and local government officials [9, 10]. Democrats are also much more incline to give positive rating to public health officials like CDC [4].
![Shows change of views from March to August of CDC and local, state elected officials and Donald Trump](image5)
There are wider partisan difference about the public health officials. [10].

Partisan differences are often wider than geographical differences in opinions about the pandemic [6]. For example, even Republicans in less-affected areas are less likely to attribute increased cases to infections rather than testing [8], demonstrating that partisan differences about the reasons of rising coronavirus case [3].
![Partisan differences are evident in views on whether the increase in confirmed cases is due to more infections or more testing.](image3)
In conclusion, partisan divides deeply influence perceptions of COVID-19 response effectiveness, with Democrats generally viewing the U.S. response and the performance of various officials more negatively than Republicans.

There are wide partisan differences in views of how public health officials, such as those with the CDC, and Donald Trump are responding to the COVID-19 outbreak [5].

The public is less positive about how public health officials are responding to the coronavirus, with virtually all of the decline in positive assessments coming among Republicans [3]. Since March, the share of Republicans who rate public health officials positively has fallen 31 points, from 84% to 53% [2]. Democrats’ views are largely unchanged over that time period (74% in March, 72% today) [2]. About seven-in-ten Democrats (72%) say public health officials have done an excellent or good job in responding to the coronavirus [10].
![Public health officials such as those at the CDC](image3)

Donald Trump gets lower ratings for his response to the outbreak than he did in March [7]. The share of Democrats who rate Trump’s response as “poor” has risen steeply since then. In March, 56% of Democrats said Trump’s response to the coronavirus was poor; today, 82% do so [9].
![Donald Trump](image3)

Partisan differences significantly impact perceptions of the response to the COVID-19 outbreak, with declining Republican support for public health officials and increasingly negative Democratic views of Donald Trump's response.

Approval ratings for public health officials, such as those at the CDC, have declined significantly from March to August [1]. Positive assessments of public health officials have decreased, with a notable decline among Republicans [4]. In March, 84% of Republicans rated public health officials positively; by August, this had fallen to 53% [9]. Democrats' views remained largely unchanged during this period (74% in March, 72% in August) [9].
![Public health officials approval ratings declined from March to August, especially among Republicans.](image4)

Donald Trump's positive ratings for handling the coronavirus outbreak have also fallen since March [6]. In March, 45% of Americans approved of Trump's performance, compared to 38% in August [10]. The partisan differences are stark: 77% of Republicans and Republican leaners approve of Trump's performance, while only 5% of Democrats and Democratic leaners say the same [2].
![Donald Trump's approval ratings from 2017 to 2020, showing fluctuations and a decline in 2020.](image2)
The share of Democrats who rate Trump's response as "poor" has risen from 56% in March to 82% in August [8]. There are also much wider partisan differences in views of the respond of the outbreak of public health officials [7].

In summary, approval ratings for both public health officials and Donald Trump have declined from March to August, with a significant drop among Republicans for public health officials and a widening partisan divide in views of Trump's performance.

Americans' perceptions of the COVID-19 response vary significantly between state governments and Donald Trump's handling of the pandemic. Positive evaluations of state government officials have declined since March, dropping from 70% to 56% [10]. However, this is still notably higher than the ratings for Trump's response.

Nearly half of Americans (48%) rate Trump's response to the outbreak as "poor," a substantial increase in criticism since March [4, 6]. The image data reinforces this sentiment, visually depicting the breakdown of ratings for various entities, where Trump's "poor" rating stands out [10].

![Poor Only fair Excellent eq 16 63 43 60 16 56 37 NET Hospitals and medical 88 centers in your area Public health officials such as those at the CDC Your local elected officials Your state elected officials Donald Trump 63](image1)

In terms of effectiveness, a majority of Americans are critical of Trump's response [6]. The contrast is further highlighted by partisan differences, with Republicans and Democrats holding divergent opinions on nearly all aspects of the coronavirus outbreak [8].

In conclusion, American perceptions show a higher level of satisfaction with state government COVID-19 responses compared to Donald Trump's, with significantly more criticism directed towards the latter's handling of the pandemic.

Americans' views on the effectiveness of the response to the COVID-19 outbreak vary across different groups and officials. Evaluations of public health officials, such as those at the CDC, have declined since March, with 63% now saying they are doing an excellent or good job [2]. The ratings are also presented for the different groups handling COVID-19.
![Ratings for handling COVID-19](image4)

There's a significant partisan divide in these views, Republicans' positive ratings for public health officials have dropped considerably, while Democrats' views remain largely unchanged [3].

As for the factors contributing to the continued outbreak, a significant majority of Americans believe that a major reason is that too few people are adhering to guidelines about social distancing and mask-wearing [8].
![Major reason for continued outbreak is not enough people social distancing and mask-wearing](image1)
A smaller majority (58%) also point to the lifting of restrictions too quickly in some places as a major reason [8].

In summary, Americans' perceptions show a decline in confidence in public health officials, especially among Republicans, and identify insufficient adherence to public health guidelines and premature lifting of restrictions as key factors in the continued COVID-19 outbreak.

Americans' views on government responsibility during the COVID-19 pandemic are deeply influenced by their political affiliations [9]. The public is almost evenly split on whether state and local governments (51%) or the federal government (48%) should be primarily responsible for developing and implementing policies to limit the spread of the coronavirus [9].

![Who is primarily responsible to develop policy to limit spread of Covid-19?](image4)

Partisan divisions are evident, with 68% of Republicans favoring state and local government responsibility, while 64% of Democrats believe the federal government should take the lead [9].

Several factors are cited as major reasons for the continuation of the outbreak. A significant majority (75%) of Americans point to insufficient social distancing and mask-wearing as a primary cause [1], [7].

![Reasons the coronavirus outbreak has continued.](image1)

Other major reasons include the premature lifting of restrictions in some areas (58%), inadequate response from the federal government (53%), insufficient timely testing (49%), and unclear instructions on prevention (40%) [7]. Democrats are generally more likely than Republicans to identify these factors as major reasons [5]. Notably, there's a wide partisan gap concerning the federal government's response, viewed as inadequate by 82% of Democrats versus 21% of Republicans [5].

![Reasons for Covid-19 outbreak by Political Affiliation.](image5)

In summary, political affiliation significantly shapes perceptions of government responsibility, with Republicans favoring state and local control and Democrats preferring federal leadership, Insufficient social distancing is the most significant reason.

Americans across the political spectrum cite various reasons for the continuation of the COVID-19 outbreak, but their emphasis differs significantly based on party affiliation. A majority of Americans (75%) believe that "not enough people following social distancing and mask-wearing guidelines" is a major reason for the continued outbreak [6, 8]. This view is shared by a majority in both parties, although it is more prevalent among Democrats (89%) than Republicans (57%) [7].

![Not enough people social distancing and mask-wearing](image5)

However, partisan divides are evident in other perceived reasons. Democrats are much more likely than Republicans to attribute the continued outbreak to an inadequate federal government response (82% vs. 21%) [5, 9] and the premature lifting of restrictions in some places (82% vs. 31%) [5, 10].

![Inadequate response from the federal government](image4)

In conclusion, while both Republicans and Democrats acknowledge the role of insufficient social distancing, Democrats are far more likely to attribute the ongoing COVID-19 outbreak to government failures and policy decisions, compared to Republicans.

A majority of Americans (53%) believe that an inadequate federal government response is a major reason for the continuation of the COVID-19 outbreak [5]. However, there's a significant partisan divide in this perception.

![Not enough people social distancing and mask-wearing Restrictions have been lifted too quickly in some places Inadequate response from the federal government Not enough timely testing Unclear instructions about how to prevent the spread It is not possible to do much to control the spread Rep/ Dem/ Lean Rep LeanDem | | Total 57@ @s9 75 - i ; . 21@ @82 53) 30 @ @67 49 30 @ @47 40 20 @ @35 28](image1)

A substantial 82% of Democrats view the inadequate federal response as a major reason, compared to only 21% of Republicans [3]. Democrats are more likely than Republicans to attribute the continuation of the outbreak to several factors, with the widest partisan differences on the federal government's response and the premature lifting of COVID-19 restrictions [3]. While 57% of Republicans say an inadequate response is due to people not social distancing [7].

In summary, perceptions of the federal government's response to the COVID-19 outbreak differ significantly between Democrats and Republicans, with the general public citing insufficient social distancing as a major reason for the continuation of the outbreak.

The continuation of the COVID-19 outbreak is viewed differently through partisan lenses, particularly regarding the reasons for its persistence and the adequacy of the responses. Democrats are more likely than Republicans to attribute the continuation of the outbreak to several factors [7].

A significant partisan gap exists on whether restrictions were lifted too quickly, with 82% of Democrats citing this as a major reason, compared to only 31% of Republicans [7]. This is visually represented in the data showing differing opinions across party lines regarding the lifting of restrictions [3].
![Restrictions have been lifted too quickly in some places](image3)
There's also a stark contrast in views regarding the federal government's response: 82% of Democrats see it as inadequate, while only 21% of Republicans agree [7, 10].
![Inadequate response from the federal government](image3)
Republicans and Democrats also differ on the impact of testing with A 62% majority of Republicans say that “the increase in confirmed coronavirus cases is primarily a result of more people being tested than in previous months,” [6].
![More people are being tested than in previous months](image4)
However, most American attribute the rise to rising infections, and showing the wide partisan divide. [8]
Majorities in both parties, however, do agree that 'not enough' social distancing is a significant reason for the outbreak continuing [4].
![Not enough people social distancing and mask-wearing](image1)

In summary, Democrats predominantly blame inadequate federal response and premature lifting of restrictions for the continuation of the outbreak, while Republicans are more likely to attribute it to increased testing and are less critical of the federal response.

Americans' perspectives on the reasons for rising COVID-19 cases and the lifting of restrictions differ significantly across political affiliations.

Regarding the reasons for the rise in confirmed coronavirus cases, a majority of Republicans (62%) attribute it primarily to increased testing [7]. Republicans are relatively divided on whether they are more concerned that restrictions have not been lifted quickly enough (53%) or that they have been lifted too quickly (45%) [8].
![Republicans attribute rising cases to testing, while Democrats attribute it to infections.](image1)
Democrats overwhelmingly attribute the rise in cases primarily to more infections (80%) [7]. A significant 90% of liberal Democrats believe increased case counts are due to increased infections, compared to 73% of conservative and moderate Democrats [5].
![Democrats are more concerned about restrictions lifting too quickly.](image2)
Overwhelmingly, both liberal (93%) and conservative/moderate Democrats (88%) are more concerned that state restrictions have been lifted too quickly [1].

There's a wide partisan gap concerning the reasons for the outbreak continuing. 82% of Democrats believe some places were too quick to ease restrictions, while only 31% of Republicans say the same [9].
![Democrats are more likely to attribute the continuing outbreak to restrictions being lifted too quickly.](image5)
Most Americans (60%) attribute the rise in confirmed cases more to rising infections than to a rise in testing, with a wide partisan divide in these views [10].

In conclusion, Democrats predominantly attribute rising COVID-19 cases to increased infections and believe restrictions were lifted too quickly, whereas Republicans are more likely to attribute the rise to increased testing and are divided on the pace of lifting restrictions.

There's a strong correlation between views on the causes of increased COVID-19 cases and opinions on lifting restrictions, with significant differences across political lines.

Republicans are more likely to believe that the increase in confirmed cases is primarily due to increased testing [5, 9]. A majority of Republicans (62%) attribute the rise in cases to more testing rather than new infections [5, 9]. This view is particularly strong among conservative Republicans [5]. Consequently, a larger portion of Republicans (53%) are more concerned that restrictions have not been lifted quickly enough [1].
![Opinions by political affiliation on whether more people are being tested or if there are more new infections.](image5)

Conversely, Democrats overwhelmingly believe that the rise in cases is mainly due to increased infections, not just more testing [7, 9]. 80% of Democrats attribute the increase to new infections [9]. This belief is stronger among liberal Democrats (90%) compared to conservative and moderate Democrats (73%) [7]. As a result, Democrats overwhelmingly express concern that restrictions have been lifted too quickly [2, 6]. There is a wide partisan gap regarding lifting COVID-19 restrictions too quickly (82% of Democrats, 31% of Republicans) [6].
![Reasons for the continuation of the outbreak according to political affiliation.](image3)

In summary, Republicans tend to believe increased cases are due to more testing and thus are more likely to favor lifting restrictions, while Democrats largely attribute the increase to more infections and are more concerned about restrictions being lifted too quickly.

A significant majority of adults, 76%, either strongly or somewhat favor requiring all voters to show government-issued photo identification to vote [9]. However, there are notable differences in these preferences across racial and political lines.

Republicans overwhelmingly support this policy, with 93% in favor [3].

![Views of requiring all voters to show government-issued photo ID in order to vote.](image2)

In contrast, views among Democrats are more divided and vary by race. While a narrow majority of White Democrats (54%) favor requiring photo ID, larger shares of Black (65%), Hispanic (72%), and Asian Democrats (71%) support this requirement [2].
![Support for automatic voter registration.](image4)

There are differences when it comes to support of policies, White adults are less supportive than Hispanic adults [7].
Black adults also show lower support levels for restrictive voting policies [8].

In conclusion, while a majority of Americans support requiring photo ID to vote, support is significantly higher among Republicans, and among Black, Hispanic, and Asian Democrats compared to White Democrats.

There are notable racial and ethnic differences in how people view voting policies [3]. When it comes to requiring government-issued photo identification, a majority of Black (65%), Hispanic (72%), and Asian (71%) Democrats support this policy [2].
![A voter should only be allowed to vote early or absentee if they havea Any voter should have documented reason for not _ the option to vote voting in person on Election Day early or absentee](image4)
For early or absentee voting, White Democrats are more supportive of allowing all voters this option than Democrats of other races and ethnicities [10].
![White 54® @96 Black 65@ Hispanic 72@ @90 Asian* 71@](image5)
Conversely, Black adults show lower levels of support for restrictive policies, such as requiring photo identification [4]. Black Americans distinctively favor more expansive voting policies. [6].

In conclusion, racial and ethnic differences influence support for voting policies, with Black Americans often favoring more expansive policies and varying levels of support among White, Hispanic, and Asian Americans for policies like photo identification and early voting.

There are varying views on the requirement for government-issued photo identification to vote, influenced by both racial and political affiliations. A significant majority of adults, 76%, either strongly or somewhat favor requiring all voters to show government-issued photo identification [10]. However, this support varies across racial groups.

Within the Democratic party, a narrow majority of White Democrats (54%) favor this requirement, while larger shares of Black (65%), Hispanic (72%), and Asian Democrats (71%) support it [6]. This is visually represented in the data showing approval rates across different racial groups within the Democratic party.
![White 54@ @96

Republicans show stronger support for photo identification requirements, with 81% strongly favoring it, compared to 30% of Democrats [9].

In terms of voting accessibility policies, there are also notable differences. White Democrats are more supportive of allowing all voters to vote early or absentee than Democrats of other races and ethnicities [2].

 In contrast, White Republicans are less supportive of automatically registering all eligible citizens to vote compared to Hispanic Republicans (35% vs 51%) [3, 7].

Black adults are substantially more likely than those of other races and ethnicities to favor allowing people convicted of felonies to vote after serving their sentences (85% of Black Americans favor this policy) [7].

Overall, perspectives on voter ID requirements and voting accessibility policies vary significantly, with racial and ethnic differences present within both major political parties, and Republicans are more likely to support strict voter ID laws than Democrats.

Americans generally favor the option for any voter to vote early or absentee, with slightly more than 60% supporting this view [6]. However, there are significant differences across political and demographic groups.

Partisanship plays a crucial role, with only 38% of Republicans supporting no-excuse early or absentee voting, compared to 84% of Democrats [3, 7]. The share of Republicans supporting this has decreased by 19 percentage points [7]. Ideological divides within the Republican party also exist. ![Ideological Divide among Republicans and Democrats on Early or Absentee Voting](image1) Conservative Republicans are more likely (70%) to require documented reasons for early or absentee voting, while moderates and liberals are evenly split [9].

Among Republicans, those with recent experience voting early or absentee are more likely to support no-excuse absentee voting. ![Absentee Voting Experience Among Republicans and Democrats](image4) Specifically, 52% of Republicans who voted absentee favor this option, compared to 35% of early in-person voters and 22% of those who voted in person on Election Day [10].

White Democrats are more supportive of allowing all voters to vote early or absentee, while among the Republicans the support of no-excuse early and absentee voting among White Republicans is less than Hispanic Republicans [2]. ![Early and Absentee Voting support among different races](image5)

Regarding the proposal by House Democrats for redistricting, nearly half of U.S. adults approve of requiring states to use redistricting commissions with equal numbers of Democrats and Republicans. ![Public Support for Redistricting Commissions](image2) Only 13% disapprove of this proposal, while 38% are unsure [8].

In summary, Democrats and those who voted absentee in 2020 are generally more supportive of no-excuse early and absentee voting, while Republicans, especially conservative Republicans, show less support and have become more restrictive in their views. Public opinion on independent redistricting commissions is generally favorable.

The data indicates varying perspectives on voting methods and redistricting based on political affiliation.

A proposal to end state legislatures' control over congressional redistricting and instead use redistricting commissions composed of equal numbers of Democrats and Republicans is supported by about half of U.S. adults [1, 3]. Disapproval is low, at 13%, with 38% unsure [3]. Republicans are somewhat more likely to disapprove (19%) than Democrats (8%), and also more likely to be unsure (42% vs. 32%) [8].
![Disapprove Approve = Not sure](image5)

Regarding voting methods, there's a clear partisan divide. Republicans and Republican leaners who voted absentee or by mail in the 2020 election are more likely to favor no-excuse absentee or early voting [2, 6]. Specifically, 52% of Republicans who voted absentee or by mail favor this, compared to only 35% of early in-person GOP voters and 22% of those who voted in person on Election Day [7].
![All 2020 voters](image3)

Ideological differences within the Republican party also influence views. Conservative Republicans are more likely (70%) to say voters should be required to provide documented reasons for voting absentee or early, while moderates and liberals are evenly divided [9].

In conclusion, there are diverse opinions on voting and redistricting, with Republicans more divided on absentee voting based on their own voting experience and ideology, while Democrats are quite support the idea.

There's a partisan divide regarding "no excuse" early and absentee voting, as well as automatically registering all eligible citizens to vote [5].

Regarding "no excuse" early and absentee voting, Republicans' views have significantly shifted since 2018, while Democrats' views have remained relatively stable [3, 5]. In 2018, a majority of Republicans (57%) supported allowing any voter to vote early or absentee without a documented reason. By 2021, this figure had dropped to 38% [5].
![Views on absentee voting over time](image2)
In contrast, Democrats have consistently shown high support for "no excuse" early and absentee voting, with 84% in favor in 2021, virtually unchanged in recent years [5].

As for automatically registering all eligible citizens to vote, Democrats' views have remained much more stable [1]. In 2021, 82% of Democrats favored automatically registering all eligible citizens to vote [1, 5].
![Party views on automatic voter registration](image3)
Republicans, however, have become less supportive of this measure. In 2018, 49% of Republicans supported automatic voter registration, but this dropped to 38% by 2021 [7].

In Summary: from 2018 to 2021, Republican support for "no excuse" early or absentee voting decreased, and their support for automatically registering all eligible citizens to vote also declined, while Democratic views on both issues remained consistently high.

There's a divergence in partisan views regarding making Election Day a national holiday. While Democrats are 7 percentage points more likely to favor this policy in 2021 compared to three years prior, Republican support has remained relatively stable [1]. Specifically, in 2021, 59% of Democrats and Democrat leaners favored making Election Day a national holiday, which has not change since 2018. 55% of Republican and Republican leaners favored it.

![Making Election Day a National Holiday](image2)

Conversely, views on requiring all voters to show government-issued photo identification to vote have seen little change since 2018 [6]. Republicans overwhelmingly support this policy.

![Requiring all voters to show government-issued photo ID in order to vote](image2)

In detail, 93% of Republicans and those who lean Republican favored requiring photo ID in 2021, nearly unchanged from 91% in 2018 [6]. Democrats' support saw a decrease, with 61% in favor in 2021, compared to 63% in 2018. Democrats are more likely to strongly favor proposals aimed at making it easier to vote, while Republicans are more likely to strongly support requiring voters to show a photo ID [9]. For example, 81% of Republicans strongly favor photo ID requirements, compared to only 30% of Democrats [4].

In summary, Democratic support for making Election Day a national holiday has increased slightly, while Republican support has remained constant; both parties' support for requiring photo ID to vote has remained largely unchanged, with Republicans overwhelmingly supporting it and a smaller majority of Democrats in favor.

Latino registered voters have consistently favored the Democratic Party over the Republican Party by a nearly two-to-one margin from 2019 to 2022 [2]. Specifically, in 2022, 64% of Latino voters identified with or leaned toward the Democratic Party, compared to 33% for the Republican Party [2]. This trend is visually represented in the data, showing a consistent preference for the Democratic Party over the years.
![Latino registered voters lean Democratic, but the margin has narrowed slightly since 2019](image2)
However, there's a segment of Latino voters whose future party affiliation remains uncertain [3].

In terms of specific voting preferences in the 2022 congressional elections, about 53% of Latino registered voters indicated they would vote for or lean toward the Democratic candidate, while 28% favored the Republican candidate [9]. A significant portion (18%) said they would vote for another candidate or were unsure [9].

Demographic factors play a crucial role in these preferences. For instance, among Latino registered voters, those who consider being Latino extremely or very important to their identity are more likely (60%) to vote for the Democratic candidate [7].
![Preferences among Latino voters, those who consider being Latino extremely or very important to their identity are more likely to vote for the Democratic candidate.](image4)
The importance of various issues has also shifted. While the economy remains the top concern for Latino voters in 2022, with 80% considering it very important [10], abortion has significantly risen in importance [6, 8]. In March, only 42% of Hispanic voters considered abortion a very important issue, but this figure jumped to 57% by August, following the Supreme Court's decision to end the federal guarantee of a right to legal abortion [8]. Other top issues include healthcare (71%), violent crime (70%), education (70%), and gun policy (66%) [10].
![The economy is the top concern for Latino voters.](image3)

In summary, Latino voters have maintained a strong preference for the Democratic Party from 2019 to 2022, with the economy remaining their top concern, while abortion has significantly increased in importance, and demographic factors like the strength of Hispanic identity influence their voting preferences.

Hispanic Democrats and Republicans differ significantly on both Trump's future political role and the perception of racial discrimination.

A large majority of Hispanic Democrats and Democratic leaners (94%) do not want Trump to remain a national political figure [7].  
![Trump should not remain a national political figure](image4)
In contrast, 63% of Hispanic Republicans and GOP leaners want Trump to remain a national political figure [7], with 41% of them, saying he should run for president in 2024[7].
![Run for president himself](image4)

Regarding racial discrimination, 73% of Latino Democrats and Democratic leaners believe that people not seeing racial discrimination where it exists is a bigger problem [1].
![People NOT seeing racial discrimination where it really DOES exist](image5)
Conversely, 62% of Republicans and Republican leaners say it is a bigger problem that people see racial discrimination where it does not exist [1].
![People seeing racial discrimination where it really does NOT exist](image5)

In summary, Hispanic Democrats largely oppose Trump's continued political involvement and are concerned about the denial of racial discrimination, while Hispanic Republicans generally support Trump's continued influence and are more concerned about false perceptions of racial discrimination.

Hispanic registered voters' opinions on Donald Trump's continued political involvement are strongly correlated with their party affiliation and views on other key issues [3]. A significant majority (73%) of Hispanic registered voters believe Trump should not remain a national political figure [6, 8], with this view being particularly strong among Latino Democrats (94%) [6, 8].
![Trump should not remain a national political figure](image4)
In contrast, 63% of Hispanic Republicans want Trump to stay in politics, with 41% of them even supporting his run for president in 2024 [6].

Regarding racial discrimination, there's a partisan divide among Latinos, similar to the general U.S. population. More Democrats than Republicans believe that people not seeing racial discrimination is a significant problem [9].
![People NOT seeing racial discrimination where it really DOES exist](image5)

On gun policy, a substantial majority of Hispanics (73%) prioritize controlling gun ownership over protecting gun rights [7]. This stance is more pronounced among Hispanic Democrats (85%) compared to Hispanic Republicans (45%) [7].
![Protect the right of Americans to own guns Control gun ownership](image3)
In conclusion, Hispanic registered voters' views on Trump's political future are significantly influenced by their partisan alignment, and these views are interwoven with their perspectives on issues like racial discrimination and gun control.

Hispanic Democrats and Republicans differ significantly in their views on Donald Trump's political future. A large majority of Hispanic Democrats and Democratic leaners (94%) believe that Trump should not remain a national political figure [6], as shown in the data. ![Trump should not remain a national political figure](image5). Conversely, 63% of Hispanic Republicans and GOP leaners want Trump to remain a national political figure, with 41% even suggesting he should run for president in 2024 [6].

When it comes to perceptions of racial discrimination, there is also a notable divide. A significant portion of Latino Democrats (73%) believe that the bigger problem is people not seeing racial discrimination where it really does exist [10]. ![People NOT seeing racial discrimination where it really DOES exist](image2). In contrast, 62% of Latino Republicans and Republican leaners believe the bigger problem is people seeing racial discrimination where it does not exist [10].

In summary, Hispanic Democrats largely oppose Trump's continued political involvement and are concerned about overlooked racial discrimination, while Hispanic Republicans mostly support Trump's continued influence and are concerned about perceived racial discrimination.

Hispanic perceptions of both socialism and capitalism show variance across political affiliations. Hispanic Republicans and Republican leaners have a more positive view of capitalism (68%) compared to Hispanic Democrats and Democratic leaners (50%) [1].

The views on socialism are notably different between the two political groups. Hispanic Democrats and Democratic leaners are split in their views of socialism (48% negative vs. 50% positive) [8].
![Socialism](image5)
In contrast, views among different age groups reveal significant differences. Younger Hispanics, aged 18 to 29, are more evenly divided in their views of socialism, with 46% reporting a positive impression [5, 6].
![Socialism](image5)
However, majorities of older Hispanics, specifically those aged 50 to 64 (60%) and 65 and older (61%), express a negative impression of socialism [5].
![feelings about socialism](image1)
This indicates a generational divide in the perception of socialism within the Hispanic community.

In summary, Hispanic perceptions of capitalism and socialism vary significantly by political affiliation, with Republicans favoring capitalism more than Democrats, and by age, with younger Hispanics being more open to socialism than older Hispanics.

Hispanics' views on socialism and capitalism vary significantly across political affiliations.

When it comes to socialism, Hispanic Democrats and Democratic leaners are split, with 50% viewing it positively and 48% negatively [4]. This contrasts with the views of all Hispanics, where a larger share has a negative impression of socialism (53%) than a positive one (41%) [5]. ![All Hispanics, Democrats, and Republicans have different views on socialism.](image3)

As for capitalism, about two-thirds of Hispanic Republicans and Republican leaners (68%) have a positive view, which is a greater share than among Hispanic Democrats and Democratic leaners (50%) [6]. ![All Hispanics, Democrats, and Republicans have different views on capitalism.](image1) Overall, Hispanics have a more positive view of capitalism (54%) than a negative one (41%) [5].

In summary, Hispanic Democrats are divided on socialism, while Hispanic Republicans are more positive towards capitalism.

In summary, there is significant variation in how different Latino demographic groups perceive the efforts of political parties, suggesting a divided and complex political landscape where support is not uniformly distributed.

Latino registered voters tend to favor the Democratic Party over the Republican Party by a significant margin, with a nearly two-to-one preference (64% vs. 33%) [2]. This preference has remained relatively stable in recent years [2].
![Party affiliation among Latino registered voters](image2)
There are notable differences in how different political affiliations perceive each party's efforts. A majority of Hispanic Republicans (56%) believe the Democratic Party works hard to earn Latinos' votes [1]. Conversely, 35% of Hispanic Democrats believe the Republican Party works hard to earn Latinos' votes [1].

When it comes to whether the parties genuinely care about Latinos, 36% of Latino Republicans believe the Democratic Party does, while 21% of Latino Democrats believe the Republican Party cares [8].
![Views on whether parties care about and work hard to earn Latinos' votes, by party affiliation](image5)
About half of Hispanics see little to no difference between what the Democratic and Republican parties stand for [5].
![% of Hispanics who say there is __ in what the Democratic and Republican parties stand for](image3)

In conclusion, perceptions of Democratic and Republican efforts to engage Latino voters vary significantly between affiliations, with Latino Democrats more likely to acknowledge the efforts of the Democratic Party, and vice versa, and these differing views are reflected in the consistent party affiliation trends among Latino voters in recent years.

Hispanic individuals exhibit diverse views on the differences between the Democratic and Republican parties, as well as their support for each party. About half of Hispanics do not see a great deal of difference between what the Democratic and Republican parties stand for [6]. Specifically, 45% see a great deal of difference, 36% see a fair amount of difference, and 16% see hardly any difference at all between the parties [6]. This perception is further illustrated by the breakdown among party affiliations, where 47% of Hispanic Democrats and Democratic leaners, and 48% of Hispanic Republicans and Republican leaners, believe there is a great deal of difference between the parties [6].
![A great deal of difference A fair amount of difference Hardly any difference at all](image5)

Latino registered voters predominantly identify with or lean toward the Democratic Party over the Republican Party by nearly a two-to-one margin (64% vs. 33%) [8]. Party affiliation among Latinos has remained relatively stable in recent years [10].
![Democratic Party Republican Party](image2)

Majorities of Latino adults express positive views of the Democratic Party [9]. 71% say the Democratic Party works hard for Latinos' votes, 63% believe it “really cares about Latinos,” and 60% feel it represents the interests of people like them [9]. In contrast, fewer Latinos express the same sentiments about the Republican Party, although 45% say the GOP “works hard to earn the votes of Latinos” [9].
![... “works hard to earn Latinos’ votes” describes my views __ ... “really cares about Latinos” describes my views __ ... represents the interests of people like you __](image4)

Perceptions of how well each party cares about Latinos vary significantly by political affiliation:
![The Democratic Party really cares about Latinos" describes my views __ The Republican Party really cares about Latinos" describes my views __](image1)

In conclusion, while a significant portion of Hispanics see little difference between the two major parties, a majority favor the Democratic Party, with stable party affiliation over time, and views on each party vary significantly based on political leanings.

Latino voters' views on the differences between the Democratic and Republican parties have shown some nuances. While a significant portion of Latino registered voters identify with or lean toward the Democratic Party over the Republican Party by nearly a two-to-one margin (64% vs. 33%) [6], the perception of a stark difference between the parties isn't universally held. Party identification has shifted little over the past few years [6].
![Latino registered voters’ party affiliation has not changed much in recent years](image2)
About half of Hispanics do not see a great deal of difference between what the Democratic and Republican parties stand for [1]. Specifically, 45% see a great deal of difference, while 36% say there is a fair amount of difference, and 16% say there is hardly any difference at all [1].

![Percentage of hispanics who stated how much of a difference exists between Democratic and Republican parties.](image1)

This perception is relatively consistent across party lines, with 47% of Hispanic Democrats and Democratic leaners and 48% of Hispanic Republicans and Republican leaners saying there is a great deal of difference between the parties [1].
![Percentage of hispanics who stated how much of a difference exists between Democratic and Republican parties.](image1)

The impact of these views is that Latino registered voters' future party affiliation remains uncertain [10].

In conclusion, a significant portion of Latino voters do not perceive major differences between the Democratic and Republican parties, which could explain the relative stability of their party affiliations in recent years, although they still lean towards Democrats.

A majority of Americans (71%) believe that STEM jobs offer better compensation than jobs in other industries [3, 8]. This perception is consistent across those working in STEM positions and those in other kinds of jobs [6]. Specifically, the view that STEM jobs offer higher pay is widely held [4].
![Offer higher pay](image4)
When considering job characteristics, men and women in STEM jobs value flexibility to balance work and family obligations similarly [9, 10]. However, they diverge on other job characteristics [9]. A higher share of men than women in STEM say that having higher pay and opportunities for promotion is important to them when choosing a job [9].
![Characteristics men and women in STEM value about the same diff.](image1)
Conversely, women in STEM jobs are more inclined to consider a job that focuses on helping others as important to them (59%) compared with men in STEM jobs (31%) [9].

In summary, while both genders value work-family balance, men in STEM prioritize higher pay and promotion opportunities more than women, whereas women in STEM place greater importance on jobs that help others.

Men and women in STEM share a common desire for job flexibility to balance work and family life [7, 9].
![Having flexibility to balance work/family 76%](image4)
However, their priorities diverge in other areas [7]. Women in STEM are considerably more likely than their male counterparts to value jobs that focus on helping others, with 59% of women versus 31% of men prioritizing this aspect [1, 7].
![Having a job focused on helping others](image4)
Conversely, men in STEM tend to place greater importance on factors such as higher pay and opportunities for promotion [7].

These differences in job values may relate to the perceived difficulties women face in STEM. Many Americans believe that a lack of early encouragement for girls is a major reason for their underrepresentation in STEM fields [5].
![Not encouraged to pursue STEM from early age](image3)
This is further reinforced by the experiences of women in STEM, many of whom report facing discrimination and feeling that their gender has hindered their success [3]. About half of women in STEM jobs (48%) believe that gender discrimination in recruitment, hiring, and promotions is a major reason there are not more women in STEM, compared with 29% of men [10].
![Face discrimination in recruitment, hiring, promotion](image3)
Suggestions for attracting more women and minorities to STEM often emphasize the importance of quality education, early encouragement, and ongoing support [8]. One suggestion is to design K-8 education to engage more girl, with teachers that encourage more women in STEM [4].

In summary, while both men and women in STEM value flexibility, women place a higher premium on helping others, whereas men prioritize pay and advancement, and these differing values are connected to perceived barriers like lack of early encouragement and discrimination faced by women in the STEM field.

Multiple factors contribute to the underrepresentation of women, blacks, and Hispanics in STEM fields, though some reasons differ between the groups.

A significant reason cited for the underrepresentation of both women and minorities is a lack of encouragement from an early age to pursue STEM [6]. Specifically, 39% of Americans believe this is a major reason why there are not more women in STEM, while 41% say the same about blacks and Hispanics [6]. The perception is visually confirmed by the provided chart.
