Discrimination in recruitment, hiring, and promotions is perceived differently among these groups [3, 5, 8]. About half (48%) of women in STEM jobs believe gender discrimination is a major reason for the lack of women in STEM, compared to only 29% of men in STEM jobs [3]. Among blacks in STEM jobs, 72% cite racial discrimination as a major reason for underrepresentation, whereas only 27% of whites and 28% of Asians agree [8].

Limited access to quality education is considered a major factor for blacks and Hispanics, with 42% of Americans identifying it as a key reason [9].

In conclusion, the main reasons for underrepresentation in STEM differ, with discrimination being a more prominent factor for women and blacks, while lack of early encouragement is significant for all groups, and limited access to quality education is especially crucial for blacks and Hispanics.

STEM workers generally have higher education levels than non-STEM workers, with 65% holding at least a bachelor's degree compared to 32% of non-STEM workers [7]. A significant portion of STEM workers (29%) have earned a master's, doctorate, or professional degree, which is much higher than the 12% of non-STEM workers with advanced degrees [7].
![Education levels of Non-STEM workers](image2)
The distribution of employment sectors is similar for both STEM and non-STEM workers. The majority of both groups work for private, for-profit employers (66%) [8].
![Employment sector distribution for All employed, STEM jobs, and Non-STEM jobs](image4)
However, there are variations within STEM fields. Engineers and architects (82%) and computer workers (77%) are more likely to work for private employers [8]. Fewer healthcare practitioners and technicians work in the private, for-profit sector (58%), with almost a quarter (23%) working for not-for-profit employers [8].

In summary, while STEM workers generally have higher education levels, the distribution across major employment sectors (private, non-profit, government) is similar to that of non-STEM workers, although there are variations within specific STEM fields.

STEM workers generally have higher levels of education compared to non-STEM workers [6]. Approximately 65% of STEM workers have at least a bachelor's degree, which is about twice the percentage of non-STEM workers (32%) with the same level of education [6]. Additionally, around 29% of STEM workers hold a master's, doctorate, or professional degree, significantly more than the 12% of non-STEM workers with advanced degrees [6].

![Educational Attainment Comparison Between STEM and Non-STEM Workers](image2)

The distribution of educational attainment is visually represented, highlighting the differences between STEM and non-STEM workers [image2].

Most STEM workers, about 66%, are employed in the private, for-profit sector, a figure similar to that of all employed adults [4]. The distribution across sectors, including not-for-profit, government, and self-employment, is also detailed, providing a comprehensive view of where STEM and non-STEM workers are employed [image3]. A small number of the stem worker are self employed [3].

![Employment Sector Distribution for All Employed, STEM, and Non-STEM Workers](image3)

In summary, STEM workers are more likely to have higher educational qualifications than non-STEM workers, with the majority in both groups working in the private, for-profit sector.

Experiences of discrimination in STEM jobs differ significantly among racial groups. Black STEM employees are especially likely to report experiencing discrimination at work due to their race or ethnicity [3, 5]. A significant 62% of Black individuals in STEM fields report such experiences [5, 7]. This is substantially higher than the reported experiences of other racial groups, with 44% of Asians, 42% of Hispanics, and only 13% of Whites in STEM jobs reporting racial/ethnic discrimination [5, 7].
![Discrimination experiences reported by various racial groups in STEM.](image5)

In comparison, gender-based discrimination also presents a significant issue in STEM fields, with women generally reporting higher rates of discrimination than men [6]. Half (50%) of women in STEM jobs say they have experienced gender discrimination in the workplace, compared to 19% of men in STEM occupations [6].
![Gender-based discrimination percentages for men and women in STEM.](image2)

The types of discrimination experienced by women in STEM commonly include earning less than men for the same job (29%), being treated as if they were not competent (29%), and experiencing repeated, small slights at work (20%) [6]. Furthermore, in workplaces where there are more men than women, the rates of experienced gender-related discrimination at work significantly increases.
![Shows how a larger male to female ratio in the workplace impacts discrimination.](image1)

In conclusion, Black STEM employees report the highest rates of racial discrimination, while women in STEM jobs report significantly higher rates of gender discrimination compared to their male counterparts.

Women in STEM jobs who work in majority-male workplaces report significantly different experiences compared to those in majority-female or mixed-gender environments. A substantial 78% of women in STEM in mostly male workplaces report having experienced gender discrimination at work [6, 8]. This is much higher than the 43% of women in majority-female workplaces who report the same [8].

![They have ever experienced gender discrimination at work](image1)

Specific forms of discrimination are more commonly reported by women in STEM in male-dominated settings. These include earning less than a man doing the same job, being treated as if they were not competent, and receiving less support from senior leaders [9].
![Women in STEM jobs](image2)

Furthermore, nearly half (48%) of women in STEM in majority-male workplaces believe their gender has made it harder to succeed in their job [4, 8], This contrasts sharply with only 12% of women in majority-female STEM workplaces who feel the same [8].

![They have ever experienced gender-
related discrimination at work](image4)

Women in majority-male workplaces are more likely to say they feel a need to prove themselves at work to be respected by coworkers [3, 7]. The gender balance in the workplace is largely unrelated to views about gender equity for male STEM workers [7].

In conclusion, women in STEM working in male-dominated environments face higher rates of gender discrimination and feel a greater negative impact on their career progression compared to their counterparts in more gender-balanced settings.

Several factors influence whether individuals with Hispanic ancestry in the U.S. identify as Hispanic, and these factors vary across generations. Racial and ethnic identity in the U.S. is based on self-reports: "You are what you say you are" [5]. However, not everyone with Hispanic ancestry identifies as such [5].

A significant portion, 11%, of U.S. adults with Hispanic ancestry do not identify as Hispanic [3]. Many have never considered themselves Hispanic or Latino [10].
![Response Summary](image4)
Reasons for not self-identifying as Hispanic include mixed backgrounds or distant Hispanic ancestry [10].
![Reasons for Not Self-Identifying as Hispanic](image2)
Other reasons include upbringing, limited contact with Hispanic relatives, lack of Spanish language skills, and the absence of links to Hispanic culture [10]. Some individuals do not identify as Hispanic because they do not look Hispanic, identify with another race, or were born in the U.S. and consider themselves American [10].

The ability to speak Spanish is not a requirement for being considered Latino, which is view hold by majority [6].
![Spanish Language and Hispanic Identity](image5)
The perception of being a "typical American" also changes across generations [7].
![Typical American Identity Across Generations](image1)
The identification as American is the highest among the third or higher generation [1].

In summary, the factors influencing Hispanic self-identification in the U.S. include generational distance from immigrant roots, mixed heritage, upbringing, cultural links, and personal identification, with significant variations across generations.

Experiences with Hispanic cultural activities and parental pride discussions differ significantly across generations. Among self-identified Hispanics, foreign-born individuals report the highest frequency of attending Hispanic cultural celebrations, with 59% saying their parents often took them to such events [9]. This trend is visualized across generations, showing a decline in participation in cultural celebrations. ![=Often Sometimes Rarely — Never](image3)

For second-generation self-identified Hispanics, the percentage drops slightly, with 49% reporting that their parents often took them to Hispanic cultural celebrations [6]. By the third or higher generation, this number decreases further to 35% [6].

A similar pattern is observed in parental discussions about pride in their country of origin. Among immigrant and second-generation self-identified Hispanics, 57% and 50%, respectively, say their parents often talked about their pride in their roots [7]. However, by the third generation, only 33% report the same [7].

In contrast, self-identified non-Hispanics with Hispanic ancestry show markedly lower engagement. Only 9% report that their parents often took them to Latino cultural celebrations [1, 3]. Many reasons that people don't identify as Hispanic are that they have mixed background or have ancestry too far back.
![Mixed background/Hispanic
ancestry too far back](image1)

The data highlights a clear trend: as generations progress, the frequency of both attending cultural celebrations and engaging in parental pride discussions decreases among self-identified Hispanics and is notably low among non-Hispanics with Hispanic ancestry.

Experiences with Hispanic culture and identity vary significantly among U.S.-born Hispanics and non-Hispanics, depending on their proximity to their family's immigrant experiences [3]. The frequency of attending Latino cultural celebrations diminishes across generations [7]. Among immigrant self-identified Hispanics, 59% reported that their parents often took them to Hispanic cultural celebrations during their childhood [9]. This percentage drops to 49% for second-generation self-identified Hispanics [4].

![The provided image shows a bar graph with categories: "Self-identified Hispanics", "Among self-identified Hispanics" (Foreign born, Second generation, Third or higher generation), and "Self-identified non-Hispanics". The bars are color-coded to represent the frequency of attendance: "Often", "Sometimes", "Rarely", and "Never".](image3)

For third or higher generation self-identified Hispanics, the share decreases further to 35% [4]. In sharp contrast, only 9% of self-identified non-Hispanics with Hispanic ancestry reported that their parents often took them to such celebrations [5], with 60% saying it never happened [5].

Parental discussions about pride in their country of origin also show a decline across generations [7].

![The provided image shows the responses of different groups regarding how often their parents talked about their pride in their roots.](image5)

Immigrant and second-generation self-identified Hispanics are most likely to report that their parents often talked about their pride in their country of origin roots (57% and 50%, respectively) [10]. However, by the third generation, only 33% say their parents often discussed their pride in their roots [10].

In summary, both the frequency of attending Latino cultural celebrations and parental discussions about pride in their origin country decrease significantly across generations of self-identified Hispanics and are notably low among non-Hispanics with Hispanic ancestry.

Across generations, self-identified Hispanics show significant differences in language dominance, parental encouragement to speak Spanish, and participation in cultural celebrations.

Language dominance shifts dramatically across generations. Among foreign-born, self-identified Hispanics, 61% are Spanish dominant [9]. This drastically decreases to 6% in the second generation and nearly 0% in the third generation [9]. Conversely, English dominance rises across the generations, with only 7% of foreign-born, self-identified Hispanics being English dominant, increasing to 43% in the second generation [5]. The language profile is shown on this chart:
![English dominant Bilingual Spanish dominant](image5)

Parental encouragement to speak Spanish also declines across generations. 85% of foreign-born self-identified Hispanics report their parents often encouraged them to speak Spanish [6]. This percentage drops to 68% among the second generation and further to 26% among the third or higher generation [6]. The trends of how often the parents encouraged them to speak Spanish are showed in this chart:
![=Often Sometimes Rarely — Never](image2)

Regarding participation in Hispanic cultural celebrations, 59% of immigrant self-identified Hispanics were often taken to cultural celebrations by their parents when growing up [1]. This percentage slightly decreases to 49% in the second generation [3] and further reduces to 35% in the third or higher generation [3]. The trends of how often the parents take them to Hispanic cultural celebrations are showed in this chart:
![=Often Sometimes Rarely — Never](image3)

In summary, language dominance shifts from Spanish to English, parental encouragement to speak Spanish decreases, and participation in cultural celebrations diminishes across generations of self-identified Hispanics.

Connections to Hispanic heritage and language use vary significantly across generations.

Among self-identified Hispanics, a strong majority of immigrants (82%) feel connected to their country of origin [7]. This connection diminishes in subsequent generations.
![Connection to country of origin decreases with subsequent generations.](image1)
The connection drops to 69% in the second generation and further to 44% by the third generation [7].

Language proficiency also changes across generations. Spanish dominance is high among immigrant self-identified Hispanics (61%) [2], but it significantly decreases in later generations.
![The percentage of Spanish Dominant speakers falls drastically.](image5)
Only 6% of the second generation and essentially none of the third generation are Spanish-dominant [2]. English dominance, conversely, rises across generations, from 7% among the foreign-born to 43% in the next, and bilingualism is most prevalent in the second generation (51%) [5, 10].

Parents play a role in encouraging Hispanic identity through language [4]. The frequency of parents encouraging their children to speak Spanish decreases across the generations.
![Parental encouragement to speak Spanish diminishes across generations.](image2)
This trend indicates a fading connection to Spanish language use across generations [4, 8], even though there is broad support for maintaining the language in the future [9].

In conclusion, both connection to Hispanic heritage and Spanish language proficiency decrease across generations of self-identified Hispanics, with a corresponding rise in English dominance.

The language dominance shifts significantly across generations. Among foreign-born, self-identified Hispanics, Spanish dominance is prevalent at 61%, while English dominance is only at 7% [3, 5]. The second generation sees a notable shift, with 51% being bilingual and 43% being English dominant [4, 5]. By the third or higher generation, English dominance becomes the norm, with a very small percentage being Spanish dominant [3].
![English dominant Bilingual Spanish dominant](image3)
The connection to their country of origin decreases across generations. While 82% of immigrants feel connected to their country of origin, this drops to 69% in the second generation and further to 44% by the third generation [1].
![Very/somewhat Not very/not
connected connected at all](image2)
In summary, language dominance shifts from Spanish to English, and the sense of connection to Hispanic heritage weakens across successive generations of self-identified Hispanics.

The linguistic profile and connection to Hispanic heritage among self-identified Hispanics demonstrably shift across generations.

A significant majority (61%) of immigrant self-identified Hispanics are Spanish dominant [9]. This dominance drastically diminishes in subsequent generations. Only 6% of the second generation is Spanish dominant, and this figure drops to essentially none in the third generation [9]. 
![Bilingual Spanish dominant](image2)
Concurrently, English dominance increases with each generation. While only 7% of foreign-born self-identified Hispanics primarily use English, this proportion rises to 43% in the second generation and 75% in the third generation. The second generation shows a high rate of bilingualism, with 51% being proficient in both English and Spanish [2].

![English dominant](image3)
The sense of connection to their family's country of origin also weakens across generations among self-identified Hispanics. A substantial 82% of immigrants feel very or somewhat connected to their origin country [4]. This feeling decreases to 69% in the second generation and further declines to 44% in the third generation [4].
![Very/somewhat connected](image5)

In summary, language dominance shifts from Spanish to English, and the sense of connection to Hispanic heritage weakens across generations of self-identified Hispanics.

Among self-identified Hispanics, connections to their ancestral national origins tend to diminish as immigrant roots become more distant [10]. A significant majority of Hispanic immigrants (82%) report feeling very or somewhat connected to their country of origin [10]. This sense of connection is also strong among second-generation Hispanics (69%), who are the children of at least one immigrant parent [10]. However, by the third generation, less than half (44%) feel a similar degree of connection to their family’s country of origin [10].
![Connections to the home country decline even further among non-Hispanic adults with Hispanic ancestry.](image3)

The impact of Hispanic heritage on an individual's life also varies across generations [2]. Second-generation Hispanics report the greatest perceived advantage, with 52% stating that their Hispanic background has been beneficial in their lives [2]. In contrast, only 28% of immigrant Hispanics and 24% of third or higher generation Hispanics share the same sentiment [2].
![The impact of Hispanic heritage on life varies across generations.](image1)

In summary, both the sense of connection to Hispanic heritage and the perceived advantages of this heritage decrease across generations of self-identified Hispanics.

Among self-identified Hispanics, connections to their ancestral national origins diminish as their immigrant roots become more distant [7]. A significant majority of immigrants (82%) who identify as Hispanic report feeling very or somewhat connected to their country of origin [7]. This connection is also strong among second-generation Hispanics (69%), who are the children of at least one immigrant parent [7]. However, by the third generation, less than half (44%) feel very or somewhat connected to their family’s country of origin [7].

connected connected at all](image4)

The sense of connection differs significantly between generations. For instance, 82% of foreign-born Hispanics feel very or somewhat connected, compared to only 44% of third or higher generation Hispanics [7].

In terms of the perceived advantages of Hispanic heritage, second-generation Hispanics report the most significant impact [8]. About half (52%) of this group say their Hispanic background has been an advantage in their lives [8]. In contrast, fewer immigrant Hispanics (28%) and third or higher generation Hispanics (24%) share this sentiment [8].
![Beenan Not made Beena
advantage adifference disadvantage](image5)

The data indicate that the perceived advantage of Hispanic heritage is highest among second-generation Hispanics.

In conclusion, connections to Hispanic heritage decrease across generations, while the perceived advantage of this heritage is most strongly felt by the second generation among self-identified Hispanics.

Across generations of self-identified Hispanics in the U.S., perceptions of racial identity and the impact of Hispanic heritage vary significantly. Most Hispanics believe passersby would perceive them as Hispanic, but this perception decreases across generations [9]. Specifically, 78% of immigrant Hispanics believe strangers would identify them as Hispanic or Latino, a figure that drops to two-thirds among the second generation and further to 46% among the third or higher generation [10].

![How people on the street would describe you](image5)

The impact of Hispanic heritage also differs across generations. Half (52%) of second-generation Hispanics believe their Hispanic background has been an advantage in their lives [2].

![Has your Hispanic background been an advantage or disadvantage in your life, or has it not made a difference?](image2)

In contrast, only 28% of immigrant Hispanics and 24% of third or higher-generation Hispanics share the same sentiment [2].

In conclusion, perceptions of racial identity as Hispanic decrease across generations, while the perceived positive impact of Hispanic heritage is highest among second-generation Hispanics.

Generational differences significantly impact both the perception of discrimination and racial identification among Hispanics. The frequency of experiencing discrimination decreases across generations [7]. For instance, 42% of self-identified Latino immigrants report experiencing discrimination often or sometimes, a figure that drops to 29% among third or higher generation Latinos [6].

The image data further illustrates this trend:

![Often Sometimes Rarely Never](image5)

This chart shows a clear decline in reported discrimination from foreign-born to third or higher generation Hispanics. The percentage of those who report "Often" or "Sometimes" experiencing discrimination clearly decreases across generations.

In terms of racial identification, a majority of Hispanics believe that passersby would perceive them as Hispanic, but this perception diminishes across generations [8]. Among self-identified Hispanics, 78% of immigrants believe they would be seen as Hispanic, but this share falls to 46% among the third or higher generation [5]. Conversely, self-identified non-Hispanics mostly think others see them as white [3].

The visual representation of this trend is as follows:

![= Hispanic or Latino White = Black = Other](image4)

This graph indicates that the perception of being seen as Hispanic or Latino decreases across generations, with later generations more likely to be perceived as white.

In conclusion, generational differences among Hispanics lead to a decreased likelihood of experiencing discrimination and a shift in racial perception from Hispanic towards white as they move from immigrant to later generations.

Generational differences significantly impact how Hispanics identify themselves and use language. Among immigrant Hispanics, a strong connection remains with their country of origin, with 82% feeling very or somewhat connected [1]. This connection diminishes by the third generation, with only 44% feeling the same [1].

The preference for self-description also changes across generations. While many immigrant Hispanics may use terms related to their country of origin, the term "American" becomes increasingly prevalent in subsequent generations. ![Foreign born Second generation Third or higher generation](image1) By the third generation or higher, 56% primarily use "American" to describe themselves [3].

Language dominance shifts dramatically across generations. A majority (61%) of immigrant Hispanics are Spanish-dominant [10]. However, this drops to only 6% in the second generation, and by the third generation, essentially none are Spanish-dominant [10].
Speaking Spanish is not crucial for Latino identity. ![Speak Spanish No Yes Among self-identified Hispanics Second Third or higher 7 generation Self-identified Hispanics Foreign born Have a Spanish last name No Yes Self-identified 15 Hispanics Among self-identified Hispanics Foreign born 20 Second Third or higher generation](image4).

In summary, generational differences significantly affect self-identification and language use among Hispanics, with later generations identifying more strongly as American and shifting away from Spanish dominance.

The perspective on traditional versus modern values among Arab youth has shown a dynamic evolution, with a noticeable trend towards embracing modern values, while still being significantly influenced by traditional sources.

In earlier years, the influence of parents, family, and religion was notably strong, as seen in the comparative data from 2013 and 2014. ![Influence of various groups on Arab youth's values and beliefs over the years.](image2) This indicates a foundational role of traditional influences in shaping opinions and life choices.

Over time, there's a growing inclination among Arab youth to embrace modern values, although family, friends, and religion continue to play a crucial role in their lives [8]. This signifies a shift towards a more balanced integration of modern and traditional values.

The data shows, a significant percentage across various countries still believe that traditional values should be preserved [7]. The distribution of these sentiments varies considerably by country, as illustrated in the breakdown of values and beliefs. For instance, some countries show a stronger preference for traditional values. ![Traditional values are outdated and belong in the past I am keen to embrace modem values and beliefs by country.](image3)

Conversely, there are regions where a substantial portion of the youth is keen on embracing modern values and beliefs [10]. The contrast highlights the diversity in attitudes across different Arab nations.

In conclusion, while there's an increasing trend towards embracing modern values among Arab youth, traditional influences such as family and religion remain significant, with considerable variation in these views across different countries.

The rapid growth in Mountain View and Palo Alto [7] is a significant factor contributing to Caltrain's capacity issues. The image detailing ridership numbers in Palo Alto and Mountain View in 2012 shows substantial figures, with 4,461 riders in Palo Alto and 3,670 in Mountain View.
![Ridership numbers in Palo Alto and Mountain View in 2012.](image3)
This indicates a high level of demand originating from these stations.

This demand, coupled with the overall ridership growth, exacerbates the capacity issues experienced on the trains. Data reveals that many trains are operating at over 100% of their seated capacity during peak hours, with some trains reaching as high as 158% [4].
![Shows several trains are above 100% capacity.](image4)
The text mentions that trains are crowded [2, 3], with the aim to double Caltrain ridership, thus need more frequent services [6].

The increase in weekday ridership growth in Mountain View and Palo Alto directly correlates with current capacity issues, as these cities are major contributors to the overall ridership numbers, leading to overcrowded trains during peak hours.

Let's examine the CO2 emissions and vehicle ownership data for the USA, China, and Germany.

The per capita energy consumption, measured in kilograms of oil equivalent, shows a significant difference among these countries. The USA has the highest consumption, exceeding 8000 kg, followed by Germany with a value below 4000, Japan, UK, and China trails significantly with consumption under 2000 Kg Oil Equivalent.  ![World](image2)

This disparity in energy consumption directly correlates with CO2 emissions. The size of the bubbles, representing total CO2 emissions from energy use, visually confirms that the USA has the largest emissions, followed by China and then Germany [6]. The transportation sector contributes significantly to these emissions, accounting for 30.0% in industrialized OECD countries and about 20.0% globally [4]. And the sector contribution percentage in global motor vehicle demand, United States is biggest, with China.  ![United Sates](image3)

Although the graph of the comparison of world is from 2002[2], the data of the comparison highligh the significant environmental challenges.

In conclusion, the USA has significantly higher CO2 emissions per capita and likely higher vehicle ownership than China and Germany, implying a greater environmental impact regarding CO2 emissions from energy use.

Over the past 24 months, European venture capital has shown significant activity and performance [6]. The data indicates that Europe is producing higher exit multiples proportionally [10]. ![{Venture-backed liquidity events in the last 24 months}](image4)

While average exit values in Europe are approximately 25% smaller than those in the USA, the lower entry valuations and higher capital efficiency in Europe more than compensate for this difference [10]. ![{Venture Venture invested vs Exits }](image2)

Specifically, the median exit valuation in Europe is $74 million, compared to $98 million in the USA [10]. ![{Comparison of Exit Multiples and Median Exit Valuations between Europe and USA}](image3) The percentage of exits with a multiple of cash invested greater than 5x is 57.26% in Europe, compared to 41.27% in the USA. This demonstrates the strong performance and efficiency of European venture capital [7, 10].

In summary, while the USA has higher median exit valuations, Europe leads in terms of exit multiples and capital efficiency over the last 24 months.

European venture capital (VC) is demonstrating strong performance in comparison to the USA. While average exit values in Europe are approximately 25% smaller, lower entry valuations and higher capital efficiency more than compensate for this difference [1]. This leads to proportionally higher exit multiples in Europe [1]. Specifically, the median exit valuation in Europe is $59 million, compared to $88 million in the USA, but Europe shows a higher percentage of exits with a multiple of cash invested greater than or equal to 5, at 57.26% versus 41.27% in the USA.

![European VC shows a higher percentage of exits with a multiple of cash invested](image2)

European VC is driving the best exit multiples globally [3], with a disproportionately high share of successful exits [2]. This means that, relative to the investment, European VC-backed companies are generating greater returns upon exit.

![Venture-backed liquidity events are frequent in Europe](image5)

In summary, European venture capital performance surpasses the USA in terms of investment multiples, despite having smaller average exit values.

Retailers leverage in-store Wi-Fi for several key purposes. One significant application is to gather data and integrate it into various systems. The Wi-Fi network can feed information into Point of Sale (POS), Customer Relationship Management (CRM), and loyalty systems [2, 5, 7]. This integration supports a data-driven approach to understanding customer behavior and improving services.

Another critical use is to understand bandwidth usage at the application level for each store location [10].

![Vendor reputation](image1)

In terms of prevalence, in-store Wi-Fi is utilized for both company and customer use.
![Overall usage of Wi-Fi](image2)

A significant portion of businesses across various sectors, such as food, drug, convenience, mass, general merchandise, specialty, and hospitality, offer Wi-Fi access to their customers, sometimes exclusively [image2].

![In-store Wi-Fi Usage](image3)

In-store Wi-Fi is also used to collect data on various customer-related metrics. These data can be the demographics, sales conversion, time of use, social media convert, the time customers spend in the store, tracking loyalty, spots in the store, device, wifi section, and traffic counting[image4].

The main purposes of in-store Wi-Fi are to gather customer data for integration with business systems and to provide internet access, with widespread use across various retail sectors for customer access.

Retailers are leveraging in-store Wi-Fi to engage customers and run promotions [1]. Different sectors show varied approaches to Wi-Fi usage. For instance, a significant portion of businesses, spanning across General Merchandise & Specialty, Food, Drug, Conv, Mass, and Hospitality, utilize Wi-Fi for both company and customer use.
![Wi-Fi usage and customer engagement across different sectors](image5)

The primary analytics that stores employ to evaluate Wi-Fi usage include demographics, sales conversion by Wi-Fi, times of use, social media conversions, and time in store [2]. Other metrics such as loyalty/repeat visits, hot spots in the store, customer device types, guest Wi-Fi session duration, and traffic counting are also vital for understanding customer behavior and optimizing the in-store experience [2].
![Wi-Fi Usage Analytic Metrics](image3)

These insights can potentially be integrated with point-of-sale (POS), CRM, and loyalty systems to enhance the effectiveness of customer engagement strategies [3].

In summary, different sectors use in-store Wi-Fi for both company operations and customer access, utilizing a range of analytics to track usage and improve customer engagement.

The impact of Wi-Fi on customer loyalty and sales varies significantly across different retail sectors, as evidenced by the data provided.

In the Overall category, the combined effect of customer and employee Wi-Fi leads to an average increase in revenue after implementing Wi-Fi and mobile technologies. Before implementation, the average EBITA percentage was 3.4%, which rose to 5.5% after implementing customer Wi-Fi and further to 6.4% with employee Wi-Fi, marking a total increase of 17.3% ![Average increases after Avg.EBITA% | Avg. EBITA%](image1).

The General Merchandise sector shows a notable increase. The EBITA percentage starts at 6.5%, decreases slightly to 6.2% with customer Wi-Fi, but then increases significantly to 8.2% when employee Wi-Fi is added, resulting in a 32.1% total increase ![Average increases after Avg.EBITA% | Avg. EBITA%](image1).

For the Food, Drug, Convenience, and Mass sector, the initial EBITA percentage is relatively high at 9%. With customer Wi-Fi, it drops to 4.8%, and with employee Wi-Fi, it increases slightly to 5.1%, achieving an overall increase of 5.8% ![Average increases after Avg.EBITA% | Avg. EBITA%](image1). This sector, shows a revenue increase from $384.0 million to $410 million after adding WiFi, and the total EBITA increase is $26.1 million after introducing both forms of Wi-Fi.

The Hospitality sector also exhibits a positive trend. Starting at an EBITA percentage of 5.2%, it increases to 6.1% with customer Wi-Fi, and then to 7.2% with employee Wi-Fi, totaling a 17.4% increase ![Average increases after Avg.EBITA% | Avg. EBITA%](image1). The hospitality sector, saw an revenue increase from $67.1M to $83M, showcasing a total EBITA increase of $15.8 million with the addition of both customer and employee Wi-Fi services.

In summary, General Merchandise sees the greatest increase in loyalty and sales (32.1%), followed by Hospitality (17.4%), Overall (17.3%), and Food, Drug, Conv, Mass (5.8%).

Employee Wi-Fi access significantly impacts customer loyalty and sales, with varying degrees of financial benefits across different retail sectors [7].

The overall impact of customer and associate Wi-Fi shows an average sales increase of 3.4% [image5]. This translates to different profitability increases for various sectors.

![Average increases after customer and associate WiFi added.](image5)

For the General Merchandise sector, the average sales increase is 4.3%, leading to a substantial 32.1% increase in EBITA (Earnings Before Interest, Taxes, and Amortization) [image2, image5]. In dollar amounts, for an average retailer with \$850 million in revenue, this sector sees a \$55.2 million increase in EBITA after implementing Wi-Fi and mobile solutions [image4].

![Financial benefits for General Merchandise sector.](image4)

The Food, Drug, Convenience, and Mass sector reports an average sales increase of 0.6%, contributing to a 5.8% increase in EBITA [image2, image5]. For an average retailer with \$8,000 million in revenue, this is a \$41 million EBITA increase [image4].
The Hospitality sector sees a 2.5% increase in sales, resulting in a 17.4% rise in EBITA [image2, image5]. For a retailer with \$1,100 million in revenue, the EBITA increase amounts to \$15.8 million [image4].

In summary, employee Wi-Fi access enhances customer loyalty and sales across all sectors, with the General Merchandise sector experiencing the most significant financial benefit, followed by the Food, Drug, Conv, Mass sector, and then Hospitality.

The impact of WiFi access on customer loyalty and sales shows notable differences between the General Merchandise and Hospitality sectors. Looking at the average increases after the addition of WiFi and mobile technology, the General Merchandise sector experienced a substantial rise in EBITA (Earnings Before Interest, Taxes, and Amortization) [1]. Specifically, the EBITA percentage increased from 6.2% to 8.2%, marking a 32.1% increase [1]. In contrast, the Hospitality sector saw an increase from 6.1% to 7.2%, which translates to a 17.4% increase [1]. This is visualized in the following chart:

![EBITA percentage increases in General Merchandise and Hospitality sectors after WiFi implementation.](image1)

In terms of doing promotions over Wi-Fi [2], 53% of General Merchandise do promotions over Wi-Fi while the Hospitality sector is at 61% [image2].

The financial impact is significant. The average retailer revenue, profit and incremental impact after adding WiFi and mobile support has shown to be substantial [5]:

![The average retailer revenue, profit and incremental impact after adding WiFi](image5)

These figures highlight the varying degrees of impact that WiFi access has on customer loyalty and sales across different sectors.

In summary, while both sectors benefit from providing WiFi access, the General Merchandise sector sees a significantly larger percentage increase in EBITA compared to the Hospitality sector.

The addition of customer and associate WiFi in retail settings has a measurable impact on sales and profitability. Across various sectors, there's a notable increase in the average Earnings Before Interest, Taxes, and Amortization (EBITA) percentage after implementing WiFi and mobile solutions.

For the overall retail sector, the average EBITA percentage increases from 5.5% to 6.4% after WiFi and mobile solutions are added, which represents a 17.3% increase [3]. This suggests that providing WiFi services enhances the customer experience and potentially leads to increased sales and operational efficiencies.

Different sectors experience different outcomes:
*   **General Merchandise** sees an increase in EBITA percentage from 6.2% to 8.2%, marking a substantial 32.1% increase [3].
*   **Food, Drug, Convenience, and Mass Retailers** show a modest increase from 4.8% to 5.1%, a 5.8% increase [3].
* **Hospitality sector**, the average EBITA percentage rises from 6.1% to 7.2%, a 17.4% increase [3].

![Average increases after customer and associate WiFi added.](image3)

The financial outcomes can also be looked at in terms of revenue changes.
For instance:
*   In the **General Merchandise** sector, adding WiFi contributes to an increase in revenue, with the average EBITA rising from \$555.2M before WiFi to \$5850M after WiFi [5].
*   **Food, Drug, Convenience, and Mass Retailers** experienced a revenue increase from \$384.0M to \$410M, adding \$26.1M in EBITA [5].
*   The **Hospitality** sector saw its EBITA grow from \$67.1M to \$83M, an increase of $15.8M [5].
![Average increases after customer and associate WiFi added.](image5)

The data clearly indicates that the addition of WiFi positively impacts sales and profitability, with varying degrees of financial outcomes across different retail sectors. The impact of Store Networks and WiFi on Customer Experience [6] is also related to an increase the sales.

The addition of WiFi impacts sales and profitability positively across different retail sectors, with general merchandise experiencing the most significant percentage increase in EBITA, and all sectors showing notable financial gains in terms of EBITA dollars after WiFi implementation.

The period between 2014 and 2018 witnessed significant growth in both digital media and e-commerce, profoundly impacting digital advertising and online sales. E-commerce sales saw a substantial increase, with product e-commerce escalating from $13 billion in 2014 to a projected $30 billion in 2018. Travel and other online sales also grew, from $30 billion to a predicted $43 billion over the same period. ![E-commerce sales growth between 2014 and 2018.](image1) This growth indicates a strong shift towards online purchasing. The increase in smartphone penetration and infrastructure development contributed the growth of E-Commerce. [3]

The expansion of e-commerce is intertwined with the growth of digital advertising. Digital is noted as the fastest-growing sector, [image3] indicating that businesses were increasingly investing in digital advertising to capture the attention of online shoppers.
The advancement of online payments is a driver of e-commerce growth. [5, 6]
![The share of different ways for online payments.](image4)

In summary, the growth in digital media and e-commerce between 2014 and 2018 led to a substantial increase in digital advertising spending and a significant rise in online sales.

Several key factors are driving the growth of e-commerce sales. Infrastructure development and smartphone penetration are significant contributors [9]. The convenience and value proposition for customers, along with the availability of the best prices online, also play crucial roles [9].

![eCommerce sales growth from 2014 to 2018](image6)

eCommerce sales is showing significant growth between 2014 and 2018 [9]. Specifically, product eCommerce is projected to grow from $13 billion in 2014 to $43 billion in 2018, while travel and other categories are expected to increase from $30 billion to $110 billion in the same period [9]. This indicates a substantial increase in online transactions across various sectors.

![Number of Debit Card users in India (Inmillions)](image3)

By 2016, half of Indians are projected to have debit cards, which directly correlates with the increased capacity for online transactions [3]. The digital payment penetration has been the main cause that affects e-commerce sales growth [3].

The provided image quotes do not show details about the age distribution of online buyers.

In summary, the primary factors driving eCommerce growth are infrastructure development, smartphone penetration, customer convenience, and the increasing digital payments, there wasn't information about the age distribution of online buyers.

The evolution of the eCommerce market has significantly driven growth in sales, moving from an initial infrastructure and demand phase to acquisitions, payments, investment, and talent [4]. This development is characterized by a shift from inventory-led models to marketplaces, expanding into various categories such as lifestyle, furniture, jewelry, homes, and even train, airline, and movie tickets [4].
![We are here](image4)
A key driver of growth is infrastructure development, alongside increasing smartphone penetration and the availability of online payment options [4]. These factors provide customers with the convenience and value proposition of online shopping [4]. Profitability consolidation indicates a focus shift from gross merchandise volume (GMV) to profitability, and from customer acquisition to retention [3].
![2014 $3 Billion, 2018 $8 Billion](image5)
In 2014, product eCommerce was valued at $13 billion, and it was projected to reach $30 billion by 2018, indicating substantial growth over the years [5].

The provided image quotes do not offer details about the dominant age group.

In summary, the drivers of eCommerce sales growth are intertwined with the market's evolutionary stages, moving from infrastructure development to a focus on profitability and customer retention, with significant expansion in product categories and overall market value.

The e-commerce landscape in India is significantly shaped by the evolution of payment methods and changing consumer demographics. As digital payment penetration increases, the share of cash-on-delivery (COD) shipments is decreasing [6]. This shift is accompanied by a rise in EMI payments for higher-value orders, and third-party wallets are quickly gaining popularity, mirroring trends observed in China [6].

![Number of Debit Card users in India (Inmillions)](image4)

The sheer growth in the number of debit card users illustrates this trend. By 2016, it was projected that half of the Indian population would have debit cards [6], with the number of debit card users increasing from 399 million in 2014 to 584 million in 2016. The variety of payment option is also showing in the image.

![Payment integration Critical Success Factors](image7)

Major business groups, such as Tata Group [9], and Birla [7] were inspired to enter the e-commerce space, taking cues from established models like Alibaba. Payment integration is the Critical Success Factors [image7].

The evolution of payment methods, coupled with the growing number of debit card users, is a key factor driving the expansion and diversification of e-commerce opportunities in India.

The landscape of online retail payment methods in India underwent significant changes between 2013 and 2016. Initially, Cash on Delivery (COD) was a prevalent mode of payment.  However, with increasing digital payment penetration, the share of COD shipments started to reduce [6].
![Digital payments penetration reduce COD](image1)
The increase in order values led to a rise in EMI payments, and third-party wallets gained popularity due to their strong value proposition [6].
![EMI payments increased](image4)
 By 2016, it was projected that half of Indians would have debit cards, indicating a substantial shift towards digital payment methods [6].
![Half of Indians hold debit card](image3)
The exact impacts on gross margin contribution per online retail categories by transactions is not specifically detailed in provided source, but the shift in payment of online retail is mentioned.

The landscape of online retail payments in India underwent significant changes between 2013 and 2016, directly impacting e-commerce platforms. There's a predicted increase in the number of debit card users, reaching 584 million by 2016 [6]. ![45% of Indians](image5). This means that by 2016, half of the Indian population was expected to have debit cards [10].

This growth in debit card usage, along with the rise of digital payment options, has led to a predicted decrease in the share of cash-on-delivery (COD) shipments. Concurrently, higher order values are driving an increase in EMI payments [10]. The value proposition of third-party wallets is recognized, anticipating their rapid adoption, mirroring trends observed in China [10].

E-commerce platforms need to adapt by integrating a variety of payment options.
![Widest Selection](image2). Payment integration is cited as a critical success factor for e-commerce platforms, alongside factors like the widest selection, a great shopping experience, and competitive pricing [2]. Consumers perform comparison shopping across sites [3].

The shift in payment methods signifies a broader trend towards digital transactions, demanding that e-commerce platforms prioritize robust, diverse, and secure payment integrations to cater to evolving consumer behavior and expectations.

The shift in online retail payment methods in India from 2013 to 2016 is projected to influence e-commerce platforms by necessitating diverse payment integrations and affecting consumer behavior by reducing cash-on-delivery dependence.

The organizational structure of the Indian Space Research Organisation (ISRO) is overseen by the Space Commission, which formulates policies and supervises the implementation of the Indian space program [7]. The Department of Space (DOS) implements these programs, primarily through ISRO and other bodies such as the Physical Research Laboratory (PRL), National Atmospheric Research Laboratory (NARL), North Eastern-Space Applications Centre (NE-SAC), and Semi-Conductor Laboratory (SCL) [7]. Antrix Corporation, a government-owned company, markets the space products and services [7].

This organizational structure is visually represented as:
![Organisation](image3)

The budget allocation for ISRO across different programs for the years 2015-2016 and 2016-2017 shows the distribution among Space Technology, Space Applications, INSAT Operational, Space Sciences, Direction & Administration, and Other Programmes.
![Space](image1)

The organizational structure of ISRO involves the Space Commission and Department of Space, with budget allocations varying across programs such as Space Technology and Space Applications.

The Indian Space Programme is structured under the Space Commission and the Department of Space (DOS) [2, 3], as illustrated in the organizational chart: `![Organisation](image2)`.

The DOS implements its programs mainly through several key centers [3]:

*   **Indian Space Research Organisation (ISRO)**: This is the primary agency under DOS responsible for implementing space programs [3]. Antrix Corporation serves as ISRO's marketing arm, promoting commercial exploitation of space products and services internationally [2, 4].
*    **Physical Research Laboratory (PRL)**: Focuses on research in space and allied sciences[3].
*   **National Atmospheric Research Laboratory (NARL)**: This center in Gadanki, near Tirupati, is dedicated to atmospheric research, aiming to predict the Earth's atmospheric behavior through observation and modeling [9]. It has seven major research groups including Radar Application, Ionospheric and Space Research, and Atmospheric Structure and Dynamics [8].
*   **North Eastern-Space Applications Centre (NE-SAC)**: Located in Shillong, NE-SAC is a joint initiative of DOS and the North Eastern Council (NEC). It provides developmental support to the North Eastern Region using space science and technology and develops high-technology infrastructure [6].
*  **Semi-Conductor Laboratory (SCL)**: At Chandigarh, SCL works on creating a microelectronics base in India, focusing on the design, development, and fabrication of CMOS and MEMS devices [10].
* **Indian Institute of Space Science and Technology (IIST)**: Asia's first Space University in Thiruvananthapuram offers high-quality education in space science and technology, with Bachelor’s and Master’s programs emphasizing space-related subjects [5, 7].

Other centers like Antrix Corporation are crucial for marketing space products [3]. The geographical distribution of these and other centers across India can be seen here: `![geographical distribution of these and other centers across India](image4)`.

The budget allocation provides insights into the financial priorities of these programs. `![financial priorities of these programs](image1)` shows the budget for different program.

In conclusion, the centers under the Indian Space Programme play various roles ranging from research and development to commercialization and education, with their importance reflected in the budgetary allocations that support their respective mandates.

The National Atmospheric Research Laboratory (NARL) is dedicated to atmospheric research, with a vision to predict the behavior of Earth's atmosphere through observation and modeling [4]. This vision is supported by technology development, data collection and analysis, and modeling efforts [4]. NARL's research is structured around seven major groups, including Radar Application, Ionospheric and Space Research, and Atmospheric Structure and Dynamics, among others [10]. Specific projects, such as the LIDAR project, also contribute to its research capabilities [10].
![NARL at Gadanki near Tirupati,](image1)

The Semi-Conductor Laboratory (SCL) in Chandigarh focuses on building a strong microelectronics base in India and enhancing capabilities in the VLSI domain [8]. Its activities center on the design, development, fabrication, assembly, testing, and reliability assurance of CMOS and MEMS devices [8]. SCL has upgraded its Wafer Fabrication Lab, enabling the production of CMOS Wafer Fabrication Line, and has successfully processed designs, including complex ASICs like the Vikram Processor for Launch Vehicles [9].
![Semi-Conductor Laboratory in chandigarh](image1)

In summary, NARL's primary function is to conduct atmospheric research to predict atmospheric behavior, supported by various research groups and projects, and SCL's primary function is to develop microelectronics and enhance VLSI capabilities, supported by its fabrication and testing facilities.

The population distribution in Nepal as of September 2014 shows variations across caste/ethnicity, religion, and geographic location.

In terms of caste/ethnicity, the population is divided into numerous groups, with Chhetri being the largest group at 15.3%, followed by Bahun at 13.2%, and Magar at 7.5%. The distribution includes a wide array of other groups, each constituting smaller percentages of the total population [13].
![Caste/ethnicity distribution in Nepal, September 2014](image13)

Religiously, Hinduism is the dominant religion, making up 81.3% of the population. Buddhism follows with 9.0%, and other religions, including Christianity and atheism, constitute smaller percentages [2].
![Religious distribution in Nepal, September 2014](image2)

Geographically, the population is distributed across various regions, with the Central region having the highest percentage at 35.1%. The Eastern region follows with 22.3%, and other regions like Western, Mid-Western, and Far-Western have 18.1%,13.3%, and 5.6%, respectively [3].
![Geographic distribution in Nepal, September 2014](image3)
The population distribution by caste/ethnicity, religion, and region shows that different factors influences the population distribution across the country.

The data shows the demographic composition, focusing on rural-urban distribution and caste/ethnicity, comparing initial figures with those from September 2014.

The rural and urban distribution remained consistent between the initial period and September 2014. 83% of the respondents were from rural areas, and 17% were from urban areas [5].

![Caste/ethnicity distribution and population in September 2014.](image12)

Regarding caste/ethnicity, the provided data for September 2014 shows the distribution among various groups. For instance, Chhetri constituted 15.3%, Bahun 13.2%, Magar 7.5%, and Tharu 6.6% of the population [7]. There are some changes such as Chhetri's population changes from 16.6% to 15.3%, Bahun's population changes from 12.1% to 13.2%, and Magar's population changes from 7.1% to 7.5% [7].
![Sample composition by caste/ethnic group.](image7)

In summary, while the rural-urban distribution remained constant, there were slight shifts in the population distribution across various caste and ethnic groups from the initial period to September 2014.

Indonesian mobile internet users engage in a variety of activities, with instant messaging being the most prevalent [8]. A significant portion of users, 90%, use instant messaging (IM) daily, and 60% use it multiple times a day [8]. They have an average of 4.2 IM applications installed on their devices [8]. Games and apps are the most downloaded mobile content [image3].

Online shopping behaviors are also influenced by mobile internet usage. E-commerce users in Indonesia show a preference for various platforms, including conventional e-commerce sites (20%), social media (26%), IM groups like BBM Groups (27%), and forums/classifieds like Kaskus and OLX (27%) [8]. A comparison of offline and online shopping shows different preferences. For instance, online, shoes and bags have the highest percentages, and airline tickets follow [image1]. `![Offline and Online Shopping Comparison](image1)`

Mobile devices also significantly influence customer decisions (55%), even surpassing TV (49%) and desktop PCs (39%) [4]. This is reflected in e-commerce trends, where a notable portion of sales and traffic comes from mobile devices [3]. For example, lojai.com recorded almost 20% of its sales from mobile sources in May 2014 [3].

Mobile internet usage in Indonesia significantly drives online shopping activities, and instant messaging and E-commerce platforms.

Regarding mobile internet demographics in Indonesia, approximately 1/4th of mobile internet users are businessmen or entrepreneurs [image3]. The age breakdown of mobile internet users shows a significant portion (36.70%) are between 18-24 years old, followed by 25-35 years old (33.10%), and those over 35 (18.60%) [image3].

In terms of mobile content preferences, games and apps are the most downloaded content, followed by video, music, and themes [image2].

These demographics and content preferences highlight several business opportunities:
*   **E-commerce:** There's a significant market for online shopping, especially for fashion items, electronics, and travel tickets. Items such as Shoes, bags are popular online shopping items [image5].
*   **Mobile Advertising:** Indonesia is the second-largest market for mobile ad impressions [5], making it a lucrative area for businesses.
*   **Payment Solutions:** Carrier billing and mobile wallets like those offered by Coda Payments, Mimopay, and Mandiri e-cash are important for facilitating transactions, especially considering the large unbanked population [image1].
*   **Value Added Services (VAS):** Advertisement, revenue share, game and music are significant parts of VAS [image4].

In summary, the Indonesian mobile internet landscape presents significant business opportunities, particularly in e-commerce, mobile advertising, and payment solutions, driven by a young, entrepreneurial user base that favors games, apps, and online shopping.

Over the years, Telkomsel has consistently maintained a larger subscriber base compared to XL and Indosat.

From 2013 to 2014, Telkomsel's subscriber base increased. In 2013, Telkomsel had 132.1 million subscribers. ![image5](image5) By 2014, this number had grown to 139.3 million. ![image4](image4)

The Average Revenue Per User (ARPU) experienced a mixed trend during this period. The ARPU related to Voice and SMS services either flattened or continued to decrease. ![image1](image1) A factor contributing to the decline in SMS and voice call usage is the increased usage of data-based IM and VoIP services [1], which further reduces the ARPU [9].

The reduction of ARPU was also connected with a initiated price war [3]. However, data ARPU, will increase in long term as usage of the mobile Internet grows [7].

In summary, Telkomsel's subscriber base grew from 2013 to 2014, while Voice and SMS ARPU were declining, overall ARPU show mixed trends.

Between 2013 and 2014, Telkomsel experienced a growth in smartphone users, increasing from 38 million to 65 million. ![image4](image4) XL also saw an increase, albeit smaller, rising from 13.8 million to 16.8 million smartphone users in the same period. ![image4](image4)

In terms of ARPU, the trend from 2013 to 2014 and beyond indicates a continued decline in Voice and SMS ARPU, while Mobile Data ARPU was predicted to decrease in the short term but increase later. ![image2](image2) This shift is attributed to the increasing prevalence of smartphones, leading users to adopt data-based communication methods like instant messaging and VoIP, thus reducing their reliance on traditional SMS and voice calls [4, 5]. The overall ARPU was expected to decline until 2015, after which increased data usage and enrollment in larger data plans were projected to compensate for the declining voice and SMS ARPU [2].

The initial decline in ARPU can be attributed to intense price competition, which was instigated by government intervention [9]. However, it's noted that tariffs have reached their lowest point, suggesting that price wars would not continue [10].

In conclusion, both Telkomsel and XL saw an increase in smartphone users between 2013 and 2014, while ARPU trends reflected a shift towards data-based communication, impacting the usage of traditional voice and SMS services.

The data reveals a significant shift towards streaming across various music genres. For instance, Rock has an 82% share in streams, as part of its total activity. ![Rock has the highest total activity percentage in streams, at 82%.](image1) Pop also shows a substantial reliance on streaming.

When looking at the breakdown of music consumption, we see that streaming constitutes a major portion of total activity across several genres. ![This breakdown includes Physical Albums, Digital Albums, TEA, and SEA across various genres.](image2)

In contrast, album sales, both physical and digital, represent a smaller share across most genres, with some variation. For example, in a total activity comparison, Rock has a 57% share in album sales. ![Rock leads in album sales, with a 57% share of total activity.](image5)

The trend suggests that streaming has become the dominant mode of music consumption [4], significantly outpacing traditional album sales in the overall share of the music business [1].

In conclusion, streaming significantly dominates music consumption across most genres, while album sales constitute a smaller, though still relevant, portion, indicating a shift in how audiences prefer to access music.

The contribution of streams to total music activity varies significantly across different genres. For instance, in Rock, streams constitute 37% of the total activity, while Album Sales make up 39% and Song Sales 24% [1]. In contrast, Pop sees a much higher contribution from streams at 82%, with Album Sales at 10% and Song Sales at 8% [2]. R\&B/Hip-Hop also has a substantial stream contribution [2].

The contribution of streams to total music activity varies significantly by genre, with streams accounting for 70% of total music consumption.

We can analyze the information flow using the metrics  $S_{w p}$ and $S_{pq}$. $S_{w p}$ represents the mean significance of information flow from the text part to label words [10], while $S_{pq}$ represents the mean significance of information flow from label words to the target position [9].

In shallow layers,  $S_{w p}$ (information flow from text to label words) is high, and $S_{pq}$ (information flow from label words to the target position) is low [8]. In deeper layers, $S_{pq}$ becomes dominant [8].
![Information flow comparison across layers](image2)
This image shows that $S_{w p}$ is greater in the earlier layers, and the lines intersect as $S_{pq}$ becomes more significant in the deeper layers.

The observation that $S_{pq}$ becomes dominant in deeper layers [8] while initially being low in shallow layers [8] indicates a shift in the significance of information flow.
![Information flow dominance shift in layers](image1)
It illustrates the transition from the shallow to deep layers, showing that the claim is not true the entire time .

Therefore, the mean significance of information flow from the text part to label words is not always greater than the mean significance of information flow from label words to the target position.

The system generates a response to the user's request through several interconnected components, culminating in a natural language output. Here's a breakdown of the process:

The system maintains a continuous representation of the dialogue state using a dialogue-level LSTM [4]. Based on this state, the model generates a probability distribution over candidate values for each tracked goal slot, which is used to formulate a query to a knowledge base (KB) [4].

The policy network emits a system action in the form of a dialogue act, it conditions on the inputs from dialogue state, user's goal, and query results [9].
![System action
at turn k](image3)

The system then produces a dialogue action, conditioned on information from the dialogue state, the estimated user's goal, and the encoding of the query results [4].
![System dialogue act](image2)

Finally, the emitted system action is used to produce a system response in natural language format by combining the state tracker outputs and the retrieved KB entities, via a template-based natural language generator(NLG) [6].

In summary, the system generates a response by processing the user's request through an utterance encoder, dialogue state tracker, and policy network, then querying a knowledge base, and finally using a natural language generator to produce a human-readable response.

The SnapNTell dataset is distinguished from traditional VQA datasets in several key aspects [6]. It encompasses a wide range of categorized entities, each represented by images and explicitly named in the answers [4, 6]. SnapNTell includes 22 major categories [6], encompassing 7,568 unique entities [6]. This is a significantly larger number of categories and entities compared to datasets like ViQuAE and Encyclopedic VQA [5].

SnapNTell focuses on entity-centric knowledge-based VQA [2]. It features QA pairs that require extensive knowledge for accurate responses [6]. The questions in the dataset demand knowledge-intensive responses, going beyond simplistic binary answers [1].

In summary, SnapNTell contrasts with other VQA datasets by having more categories, unique entities, and a focus on detailed, knowledge-based answers.

DSC consistently achieves the highest F1 score across all datasets tested [10]. For instance, on the English OntoNotes 5.0 dataset, BERT-MRC+DSC achieves an F1 score of 92.07, outperforming other models [7].
![BERT-MRC+DSC achieves an F1 score of 92.07 on English OntoNotes 5.0.](image1)
On Chinese datasets (CTB5, CTB6, UD1.4), BERT+DSC outperforms the BERT-Tagger [3, 1].
![BERT+DSC demonstrates significant improvements in F1 scores on Chinese datasets.](image5)
Similarly, for English WSJ and Tweets datasets, BERT-Tagger+DSC records the highest F1 scores compared to other variations [8].
![BERT-Tagger+DSC shows the highest F1 scores on English WSJ and Tweets datasets.](image2)
, and on the English CoNLL 2003 dataset, BERT-MRC+DSC also leads in performance [7].
![BERT-MRC+DSC also leads in performance on the English CoNLL 2003.](image3)

The model that achieves the highest F1 score across multiple datasets is consistently BERT combined with DSC.

On the English CoNLL 2003 dataset, the BERT-MRC model achieved a precision of 92.33, a recall of 94.61, and an F1 score of 93.04. The BERT-MRC+DSC variation, which incorporates a Dice loss, achieved a precision of 93.41, a recall of 93.25, and an F1 score of 93.33 [8]. This represents an increase of +0.29 in the F1 score compared to the baseline BERT-MRC model.
![Performance of BERT-MRC model on CoNLL 2003](image4)
For the English OntoNotes 5.0 dataset, BERT-MRC model variations, including FL, DL and DSC were tested [8]. The baseline BERT-MRC model achieved an F1 score of 91.11. The BERT-MRC+DSC model obtained an F1 score of 92.07, outperforming the original by +0.96.
![Performance of BERT-MRC model on OntoNotes 5.0](image1)

In summary, DSC loss improved the performance of the BERT-MRC model, it increased the F1 by +0.29 and +0.96 on the CoNLL2003 and OntoNotes5.0 dataset, respectively.

The performance of "Our Approach" is benchmarked against several other methods, including STOP, RANDOMWALK, MOSTFREQUENT, MISRA17, and CHAPLOT18, on both the LANI and CHAI datasets [4]. The evaluation metrics used are stop distance (SD) and task completion (TC) for LANI, and stop distance (SD) and manipulation accuracy (MA) for CHAI [5].

The results on the held-out test dataset show that "Our Approach" achieves a lower stop distance (SD) and higher task completion (TC) on LANI compared to all the other methods listed [!["Our Approach" outperforms other methods on LANI and shows slight improvements on CHAI.](image1)]. Specifically, "Our Approach" has an SD of 8.43 and a TC of 36.9, outperforming CHAPLOT18, which has an SD of 8.78 and a TC of 31.9 [!["Our Approach" outperforms other methods on LANI and shows slight improvements on CHAI.](image1)].

On the CHAI dataset, "Our Approach" shows a slight improvement in stop distance (SD) with a score of 3.34, compared to scores ranging from 3.59 to 4.36 for the other methods [!["Our Approach" outperforms other methods on LANI and shows slight improvements on CHAI.](image1)]. However, the manipulation accuracy (MA) is similar to other methods, with "Our Approach" scoring 39.97 [!["Our Approach" outperforms other methods on LANI and shows slight improvements on CHAI.](image1)]. And, approaches such as CHAPLOT 18 and MISRA 17 fail to show significant results [3].

In summary, 'Our Approach' demonstrates superior performance on the LANI dataset and marginal improvements on the CHAI dataset compared to the other methods evaluated.

The evaluation metrics used include accuracy, macro-averaged F1 (Ma-F1), and micro-averaged F1 (Mi-F1) [3, 4]. The 'Ours' model, when combined with ONTO+WIKI+HEAD datasets, outperforms other models, including AttentiveNER++, AFET, and LNR [8].

Specifically, the results on the OntoNotes fine-grained entity typing test set are as follows:
*   **AttentiveNER++**: Accuracy 51.7, Ma-F1 70.9, Mi-F1 64.9.
*   **AFET**: Accuracy 55.1, Ma-F1 71.1, Mi-F1 64.7.
*   **LNR**: Accuracy 57.2, Ma-F1 71.5, Mi-F1 66.1.
*  **Ours (ONTO+WIKI+HEAD)**: Accuracy 59.5, Ma-F1 76.8, Mi-F1 71.8.
![Performance comparison of different NER models on the OntoNotes dataset.](image3)

The combination of the model and training data in the 'Ours' model demonstrates a clear improvement over prior work, achieving a new state-of-the-art result [8].

In summary, the 'Ours' model shows superior performance compared to other NER models, with higher accuracy and F1 scores.

The model that achieves the highest F1-value for Named Entity Recognition (NER) is the CCNN+WLSTM+CRF model, as shown in the provided data.

![Models Comparison on NER, Chunking, and POS Tagging](image4)

This model, combining Convolutional Neural Networks for character sequences (CCNN), Long Short-Term Memory for word sequences (WLSTM), and Conditional Random Fields (CRF) for the inference layer, yields an F1-value of 91.35 for NER [6]. The image shows the performance of several models on NER, chunking, and POS tagging tasks [4].

The breakdown of the model components includes [1, 6]:

*   **CCNN**: Represents the model using CNN to encode the character sequence [1].
*   **WLSTM**: Indicates the model uses LSTM to represent the word sequence [1].
*    **CRF**: Using Conditional Random Field in inference Layer [7].

This combination allows the model to effectively capture both global features using LSTM and character-level information using CNN, contributing to its superior performance [6].

![Human and Automatic Features Impact on Model Performance](image2)

This image displays that the model utilizing automatic features, specifically "+CCNN," achieved the highest F1-score of 91.35, thereby contributing most significantly to the model's performance in NER [4].

In summary, the CCNN+WLSTM+CRF model achieves the highest F1-value (91.35) for NER, benefiting from the combination of character-level features captured by CCNN, word sequence features captured by WLSTM, and the CRF inference layer.

The performance of various news recommendation methods is evaluated using metrics such as AUC (Area Under the ROC Curve) and nDCG@10 (Normalized Discounted Cumulative Gain at position 10).

A comparison of different methods is shown in the table, detailing their performance across these metrics [10]. The table indicates that neural network-based methods like CNN, DKN, and LSTUR generally outperform those using manual feature engineering, such as LibFM, DeepFM, Wide & Deep, and DSSM [10].
![Methods AUC MRR nDCG@5 | nDCG@10](image1)
From the table, LSTUR-ini and LSTUR-con achieve the highest scores. Specifically, LSTUR-ini has an AUC of 63.56 and an nDCG@10 of 41.37, while LSTUR-con shows an AUC of 63.47 and an nDCG@10 of 41.34 [1]. These results indicate their effectiveness in capturing both long-term and short-term user interests [1, 3, 7].

In conclusion, LSTUR-ini demonstrates the best performance for news recommendation based on AUC and nDCG@10 metrics.

The environmental impact of training Natural Language Processing (NLP) models is a growing concern, with substantial carbon emissions resulting from the energy consumption required for these computations [1]. When comparing CO₂ emissions from training common NLP models to familiar consumption, some training sessions have emissions comparable to everyday activities [5].

For example, the emissions from training BERT on a GPU are roughly equivalent to a trans-American flight [10].
![Estimated CO2 emissions from training common NLP models, compared to familiar consumption. ](image5)

To put it into perspective:

*   A single trans-American flight (NY to SF) for one person emits about 1984 lbs of CO₂ [5].
*   The average American's annual carbon footprint is approximately 36,156 lbs [5].
*    A car's average lifetime emissions, including fuel, are around 126,000 lbs [5].

![Estimated CO₂ emissions and cost of training the models.](image2)
The carbon emissions of some large NLP models, are not as large as a car's average lifetime, but some of them are multiple times a trans-American flight [2, 5].

In conclusion, the CO₂ emissions from training some NLP models are comparable to a trans-American flight, highlighting the significant environmental impact of developing and training large-scale NLP models.

BERT (Large) achieves the highest test median score of 0.712 [4]. The architecture of the BERT classifier involves joining the claim and reason to form the first text segment, which is then paired with each warrant and processed independently [2].
![BERT (Large) has the highest test median score of 0.712.](image4)
 The final layer CLS vector is passed to a linear layer to obtain logits, and the entire architecture is fine-tuned [2].
![The BERT architecture for argument reasoning comprehension task.](image2)
The learning rate used is 2e-5, and a maximum of 20 training epochs are allowed, with the parameters from the epoch with the best validation set accuracy being used [2].

In summary, BERT (Large) has the highest test median score of 0.712, and its architecture involves processing the claim, reason, and warrant, then passing the CLS vector to a linear layer.

The performance of BiDAF and FastQA models on the WikiHop and MedHop datasets varies significantly between the standard and gold chain conditions.

Under the standard conditions, BiDAF outperforms FastQA on both datasets. Specifically, BiDAF achieves a test accuracy of 42.9% on WikiHop and 47.8% on MedHop, whereas FastQA achieves 25.7% and 23.1%, respectively [5], as also depicted in the testing results:
![Test accuracy comparison of BiDAF and FastQA](image4)
When provided with only the documents leading to the correct answer (gold chain condition), both models show substantial improvement [9]. BiDAF's accuracy increases to 57.9% on WikiHop and 86.4% on MedHop. FastQA also improves, reaching 44.5% on WikiHop and 54.6% on MedHop.
![Comparison of BiDAF and FastQA on standard and gold chain conditions.](image2)
This shows the model's accuracy increases significantly when given only documents guaranteed to be relevant [9]. The iterative latent interactions in the BiDAF architecture are possibly of increased importance for the task, where information is distributed across documents [5].

In summary, BiDAF consistently outperforms FastQA on both datasets in both conditions, and both models perform significantly better when provided with the gold chain documents.
